While I am sure all Australians recognise that over the last 50 years there have been a lot of changes and a lot of positive things done by the state of Israel, currently both Australians and all people who are in favour of peace in the Middle East would be rather concerned about the present activities of the Israeli government.

speech.para: I think that Australia probably has as big a role to play in this as most countries have—and a greater role than some—because we were one of the first countries to recognise Israel 50 years ago. Australia has always taken a very positive position with regard to the state of Israel in the Middle East, and we have always been very supportive. That is a position that has gone across all shades of political opinion in this parliament. I think it is because Australia has taken that positive position with regard to the state of Israel that we should be concerned about the present circumstances.

I echo the point that was made by the previous speaker, the National Party whip in this place, the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), that there have been some long-running concerns about the activities of the Israeli army in southern Lebanon. Concerns have been underlined in recent days about Israel's refusal to sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. One asks why that was so, and of course the reason is that most people suspect that Israel does have a nuclear capability. We have both India and Pakistan detonating nuclear devices and talk that Iran is looking to develop nuclear devices, and that sort of instability in the Middle East is not a good thing.

More importantly, the attitude of the current Israeli government—and in particular of the Prime Minister of Israel—to the Palestinian people and the attempts by Prime Minister Netanyahu to derail the Middle East peace talks are surely to be deplored and regretted. I think Australia has a bit of an unfortunate role in this. Recently I visited the city of Hebron, where there is a centre supported by Mr Gutnick, an Australian citizen from Victoria.

If there is any proof needed that the extremist views of the people in the Israeli settlement in Hebron are unsatisfactory, it is the appalling news in the paper in the last few days about two Israeli young men from Hebron who killed a Palestinian man, the father of 12. They gratuitously killed him as he was walking along the road. They were driving along the road, lent out of the car, hit him with a baseball bat and killed him. The Israeli police said that it was youthful exuberance. If anything underlines that things have gone wrong in Palestine, it is the fact that people can kill someone and it is said to be youthful exuberance.

So while we should all accept that Israel is a country that Australia has given support to, there needs to be a time for change in the Middle East. That time has to come quickly, and the Israeli government and the Prime Minister of Israel in particular have to recognise that the goodwill of countries such as Australia exists only if people are looking for peaceful means of support and for peaceful solutions. The unfortunate experience that one gets when one visits Israel at present is that the government of Israel is not the least bit interested in finding a peaceful solution and a satisfactory outcome for the aspirations of the Palestinian people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I wish to support the motion moved by the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne). I am part of a generation that was born immediately after the Holocaust. For many of us, that event created an awareness of the inhumanity to which racism and anti-Semitism could lead, and an affinity with the state of Israel.

speech.para: Support for Israel has been a hallmark of successive Australian governments, and the relationship between our two nations has endured and indeed been fostered by the strength of the common values and commitment to democracy that the two countries share. Despite the many hardships that Israel has faced and faces, and despite the fact that Israel has effectively been on a war footing since its foundation, it has remained steadfast and unflinching in affirming democratic values and ideals.

This government has maintained the commitment to a strong relationship with Israel and to a friendship with Israeli people. It might be worth while noting that, following a recent interview with the Prime Minister, the influential Australia Israel Review commented that John Howard is possibly the best friend that Israel has in Canberra. The coalition can be proud that it has maintained its support and friendship with Israel even during times of difficulty. It is easy to be a friend during times of harmony; it is a lot harder to be supportive during times of hardship.

In Israel's 50th anniversary year we need to reflect on Israel's extraordinary achievements, on its ability to create a nation that has grown from 600,000 people to six million people, on its record of economic growth, and on its commitment to democracy. Israel has entered into a complex peace process, and that process has already borne the fruit of peace arrangements with the Palestinian Authority and the people of Jordan. There is still much ground to be covered in the final negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians, and all of us look forward to continuing progress.

Our support of the peace process does, however, need to reflect an understanding of the difficulties that Israel does face. I spoke earlier about the profound impact that the aftermath of the Holocaust had on many of my generation and about its importance in shaping an affinity with the state of Israel. Today we see a generation whose understanding of Israel is powerfully shaped by TV imagery of the Lebanon war, of the Palestinian Intifada, of riots in Israel, and of the actions of Jewish fringe extremists. What is obscured by the television images of conflict is the historical struggle of the Jewish people and Israel's precarious strategic position. The evening news clips do not illuminate the ethnic and pluralist diversity that is Israel today, nor Israel's unswerving commitment to democratic institutions, the rule of law and liberal freedoms.

Israel is a country whose size is hard to comprehend, given its international significance and impact. But, as the Israeli Minister for Communications recently noted when she visited Australia, all of Israel is less than half the size of Tasmania. Arrayed against Israel are some of the world's most ruthless and authoritarian regimes, highly militarised and non-democratic regimes that continue, despite the Oslo peace accords and the ongoing peace process, to refuse to acknowledge Israel's right to exist. This is an existential threat that Israel has come to terms with in the same way that the Jewish people have had to come to terms with their near extermination during World War II.

The magnitude of this was brought home to me recently when I attended a commemoration by the Greek government of a memorial for the genocide by Nazi forces of almost 44,000 of 50,000 members of the once thriving Greek Jewish community in Thessaloniki. The occasion did serve to highlight the shocking capacity for inhumanity which lies in some regimes and the appalling potential of intolerance and racism.

For Israel today, that historic legacy is reinforced daily by the constant threat of conflict and terrorist attack from regimes which not only refuse to accept Israel's right to exist but now have chemical and biological weapons. These are all fundamental facts that we need to consider for, as the motion underscores, despite Israel's accomplishment the struggle for Israel's survival does continue. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —Anyone listening to this discussion rather than debate today could not fail to be impressed with the way in which a question of this kind, which in other parts of the world and sometimes in Australia raises feelings of great passion, can be discussed so dispassionately, and the diversity of attitudes towards the position of Israel in the Middle East and its relationship with Palestine, the relationship between the Israelis and the Palestinians, can be discussed the way that it has been. It is desirable that questions of this kind be brought forward in the parliament so that people do have an opportunity to understand that members of this remarkable institution, in seeking to represent the interests of the wider Australian community, can speak so dispassionately, so objectively, so fairly and so genuinely about questions of this kind.

speech.para: Let me say just in passing that that observation of mine stands in marked contrast with other more recent experiences on the Australian political landscape. The fact that Australia has been a good friend of Israel has been referred to. Yes, it has been a good friend of Israel. I believe the Australian people are good friends of the Israelis. They are good friends of the Jewish people generally. They are also good friends of the Palestinians, and the Palestinians, in turn, are good friends of ours. At the end of 1993, I had the privilege of leading a delegation to the Middle East. I am very much aware as a result of the meetings that we had, the people that we met with, the places that we visited and the cemeteries that we saw, of the great admiration the people of the Middle East have for Australians and for the very great sacrifices in two world wars that were made by Australians on behalf of world peace, and in particular, of course, in expelling the invaders from those areas.

But I would like to make this observation too: although we are all friends and would seek to be friends, you are not necessarily a friend of anyone if you blindly defend them on all occasions without recognising the inadequacies, the deficiencies, the faults or the mistakes which are made. I am delighted that there has been such an array of attitudes expressed during this debate.

People of goodwill around the world would endorse most of the motion, and I congratulate the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) on bringing this forward. I think they would also endorse most of a resolution that was carried by the national conference of the Australian Labor Party earlier this year, which I believe would represent the thinking and the even-handed, fair attitude which Australians generally bring to this question. I will quote the first three paragraphs of quite a significant resolution on the Middle East:

Labor strongly supports the negotiation of a just, enduring and comprehensive peace settlement in the Middle East, based on United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, the principle of land for peace, and the Oslo Declaration of Principles concluded between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organisation, representing the Palestinian people, in 1993.

Labor continues to support the right of Israel to exist in peace and security within secure and recognised borders. At the same time Labor also supports the right of self-determination for the Palestinian people, including their right to their own independent state.
Labor welcomes the Israeli Labor Party's recognition of the Palestinian people's right to self-determination and the possibility of a Palestinian state.

I believe that expressions of that kind reflect the thinking of the broader Australian community. I am sure that they reflect as well the thinking on both sides of this parliament, and we have seen that. After the comments, the observations, that have been made during this discussion, I commend my colleagues on both sides of this chamber for the objective, dispassionate and fair and balanced way in which they have been able to express their attitudes towards this general question.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House calls on the Government to:

(1) recognise that the largely single option of a comprehensive high school system in this country is inappropriate for a majority of students at a secondary level and that this fact often leads to a perception that the public secondary school system does not meet the needs of parents and students; and
(2) encourage through differential funding a range of types of public secondary schools that among others would include a re-evaluation of single sex and technical high schools.

`It has become an economic fact of life that the strongest companies and the strongest nations are those with the strongest work forces. The high skilled, high wage economies that are thriving today can confidently look forward to continued prosperity.' So wrote David Pecaut in the 1997 July-August edition of Policy Options . He then went on to write about the system breakdown in Canada, of the deterioration of the school to work transition for young adults. He could have been writing about the exact same situation here in Australia.

Career guidance in Australian secondary schools is basically non-existent. It is common for just one person to be responsible for career guidance for up to 1,200 secondary students. It is common for the teacher responsible to be selected by what is known as the `short straw' method, and we all know what that is, and it is common for that teacher to have significant other duties as well as career guidance. The expectations placed upon the majority of career guidance teachers in this country cannot reasonably be expected to be met.

The suggestion, made by an increasing number of people, to re-examine the option of technical high schools in a 1998 context is being met in some quarters by blanket opposition from politicians, educators and education unions alike. Is this blanket opposition well founded? I am increasingly convinced that many in the anti-technical school camp dismiss the option out of hand because of their involvement or the involvement of their particular organisation in the decision in the first place.

In my state of South Australia, junior technical schools were established in 1941-42 as separate organisations. It was not until 1955 that these schools became technical high schools. In 1968 in South Australia, the technical high school and the high school branches of the education department were combined into a single secondary schools department. The choice of schools in public secondary education available to parents and students prior to this amalgamation—and, in some people's eyes, takeover—was about to disappear. Girls technical high schools and boys technical high schools and high schools all became secondary comprehensive high schools. A range of models in secondary education, supported by parents and educators in the field, disappeared. Healthy competition between the schools disappeared. Choice for parents and students disappeared. And I believe respect for public secondary education began to be diminished in the eyes of many in the community from this time. Private school administrators responded accordingly in their expansion plans to the gap and the lack of choice created by unthinking public school bureaucrats in public secondary education.

In the 1960s and early 1970s education in my state of South Australia was internationally highly regarded. That regard was delivered by an education department administered separately—primary, technical and high. Innovations in curriculum, methodology, resources and buildings were highly focused, particularly at the primary level. For example, thousands of overseas visitors went to South Australia to see new developments in school buildings. Technical schools at this time were attracting students over the full IQ range and in fact were offering public examination courses, entry to universities as well as practically oriented internal courses.

Influential people in high schools and universities were concerned that the trend for many very able young people to choose technical education was not in their best interests. High schools, in my view, were languishing during this period and seemed unable to respond to the challenges and innovations coming from primary and technical high schools. As we all know, nothing focuses an organisation more than dollars. The major report at the time, the Karmel report, on page 187 at 8.33 (d) points, in my view, to the very real reason technical high schools disappeared in my state and in other states as well:

Pupil/teacher ratios are generally more favourable in technical high schools and the expenditure per pupil is greater than in high schools, $365 per pupil in technical high schools in 1968 and $295 per pupil in high schools.

That was the real reason: money. It always is, unfortunately. Just because education is involved should not deter anyone from that view. Couple that differential in expenditure with professional envy and elitism about resources being spent at primary and technical high schools and you come much closer to the base of the reason for the elimination of technical high schools.

At this time preparations were being made to amalgamate the innovative primary division into a single R-12 department. This of course did a number of things. Choices of the types of schools for parents and students at the secondary level disappeared totally. The beneficiary of this foolhardy decision was of course the private sector. Primary education, highly regarded in the community, discovered very quickly that in the new R-12 division they would be starved of resources and, as a consequence, innovations diminished. A teacher drop in morale became commonplace as advocacy for primary schools, once taken for granted, disappeared.

The additional money pumped usually into senior secondary education did not achieve the result of restoring the credibility of public secondary education, which is in its own particular crisis and has been for at least the past 20 years. High schools served very well, as they always did, the 30 per cent of students who went on to tertiary education. However, their inability to satisfy public perceptions of the other 70 per cent did put them in somewhat of a no-win situation. Private sector schooling expanded and diversified whilst the image of public secondary education, and over the last 10 years primary education as well, seemed to be conformity bound, unexciting and innovation bare—with perhaps the possible exception of what was happening in a few exceptional schools.

Public secondary education needs diversity. A single model of a comprehensive high school is no longer and was in fact never appropriate. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has announced that Labor will, if successful at the next election, launch a major inquiry into education at all levels in this country. That inquiry is long overdue. The spending of resources on education in Australia reflects influence, history and tradition; it does not reflect a sound educational rationale. The current problems with literacy and numeracy reflect diminished real funding for primary schools over the past 20 years, to which very few people in administration or government wish to admit. The decreasing credibility of public secondary education is because it is offered as a largely single-style comprehensive high school.

If I can return to where I began in this speech, it is no wonder that school to work transition in this country is, for so many students, just a shambles. Certainly lack of choice of type of public school is not the only problem. Poverty, unemployment and lack of jobs for young people all play their part. But the system is wrong. It has been wrong for at least 20 years. And what bothers me greatly, and it is more than just a suspicion, is that vested interests responsible for those decisions 20 and 30 years ago do not want to wear the responsibility that they were wrong. They continue to argue for the status quo. That is unacceptable. I believe significant changes must occur.

It is interesting to know who these people are. They include some or all of the following, depending on whom you talk to: certain influential people from our universities, certain senior administrators from educational departments, former politicians, some current ones and prominent individuals within the teacher unions themselves. Reports like the Karmel report got most of their recommendations right but, on the choices of public secondary system available to parents and students, they got that wrong.

School to work transition in its current shambles can be traced in part, in my view, to the failure of the above to acknowledge what so many technical high school principals and staff did so naturally—set up the links between schools, industry and business. There was a failure to acknowledge the value of technical high school internal courses. There was a failure to acknowledge the special skills of so many staff in technical high schools. There was a failure to realise that many technical high schools were far more successful than traditional high schools in academic as well as practical courses. There was a failure to appreciate the subsequent demoralisation of so many technical high school teachers who were almost always outvoted on expenditure in budgetary discussions by subject discipline teachers far greater in number in comprehensive high schools.

Public secondary education needs diversity, and it needs it now. Parents and students require and need choice. That is natural and in the national interest. School to work transition will never be successful, except in special circumstances, with a single comprehensive high school system. It is time public secondary schools offered more choice in the type of school to parents and students. It is time for technical and, may I say, technological secondary education to be given another lease of life. And there is a place for single-sex schools. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—This motion is unusual not only for its nostalgic tones but also because the Labor member moving it, the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), is impliedly contradicting Labor policy. While the motion seeks to suggest that secondary education needs a Commonwealth directed overhaul, it more accurately serves to illustrate that Labor's thinking needs an overhaul. Much has happened since the election of the coalition government to refocus and revitalise secondary education. I am proud to say that not only did I grow up in the electorate of Dunkley but I also went to a government secondary school there when it was known as Monterey High School. This school merged with the nearby Monterey Technical School to form Monterey Secondary College—a comprehensive high school, to use the member for Port Adelaide's language.

speech.para: The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) pointed out recently that the coalition government want to see strong government and non-government school sectors. This strategy underlines the government's commitment to parental choice. The coalition government, I am proud to say, encourage diversity in and between schools. Our new schools policy has rightly allowed the commencement of places of learning that meet academic and curriculum standards, such as St Anthony's Coptic Orthodox College in Frankston North, not far from where I attended secondary school. Labor's policy is aimed at stifling the wishes of groups of parents who might want to establish such a new school. It is Labor who say that they will scrap the coalition government's new schools policy. It is the Labor Party that appear to shy away from parental choice.

In Dunkley, we have seven government secondary colleges, two Catholic secondary schools and two independent secondary schools. All have benefited from the coalition's generous budget provisioning at a time of fiscal restraint. The federal government is expecting to increase funding for government schools by 13.5 per cent on a per capita basis in the period from 1996 to 2000. Total federal funding for government schools will total almost $20 billion between 1996 and 2000. In 1998, under the coalition government, it is $380 million above what it was in the last year of Labor.

Funding for non-government schools is also growing impressively, albeit at a less significant rate than for government schools. This funding growth is way above inflation. In the three coalition budgets since being elected in 1996, the Howard government has provided an additional $1.47 billion for schools when compared with what Labor managed in its last year. This is a 22 per cent increase on Labor's federal funding allocation for education.

I agree with the member for Port Adelaide that we need options in education. In Dunkley, more than 70 per cent of the students do not go on to tertiary education. Secondary education is not just about preparing students for university or further study, it is also about preparing young people for their working lives and their adult lives and enabling them to secure the opportunities this nation offers.

Within the public system a range of options is available at present. Some local schools have a stronger emphasis on vocational education and training at this time, like the Langwarrin Secondary College. Karingal Park Secondary College has an emphasis on studies in information technology. Frankston High is recognised nationally as a leader in the use of computers for learning. Monterey is recognised for its commitment to helping students who have difficulty in learning. Sport, music and the arts are features of other secondary colleges within just my electorate.

I was delighted recently to provide a letter of support to Mr Bob Loader, the Chairman of the Peninsula Vocational Education and Training Cluster which has applied to the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation to accommodate and support 19 separate local secondary colleges within the cluster, 11 of them within the Dunkley electorate. It is great to see that all three sectors—government, Catholic and independent—have joined forces and are cooperatively participating in this initiative. Importantly, PVET's management committee includes two local retailers—an important sector of the local economy—as well as a member representing BHP. They are focused on helping our young people to make sensible choices.

This combined and coordinated local approach sees vocational education and training offered to students in areas as diverse as information technology, electronics, sport and recreation, some of the traditional trades, hospitality and many others. Successfully completing units offered through this mechanism gives the student a kick-start into an apprenticeship or traineeship and/or credits for a post-secondary qualification. Technical elements are very much a part of contemporary comprehensive secondary colleges.

Fewer than one in 10 students in Dunkley presently participates in vocational education offered through PVET. However, more than 70 per cent do not go on to tertiary studies, as I have mentioned. This does identify a gap. While some of this gap is addressed through school to work programs and much of it through individual student endeavour, the capacity clearly exists for further initiatives in vocational education and training. I have previously identified VET infrastructure, like the underutilised workshop and trade facilities at the Monterey Secondary College, as examples of where we could add to the cluster's activities. We are looking at how best to pursue this goal. Melbourne is one of the fastest growing cities in Australia, and there is an argument that the ASTF funding for Victoria should be increased because of this.

The coalition approach to improving future prospects for young people is clearly working. The latest figures available to me show that youth unemployment in the Dunkley electorate has declined by one-third since the election of the coalition government in March 1996. This and the 25,000 local jobs created in that period are indeed quite outstanding achievements. Programs such as jobs pathway provide a direct school to industry link through the hard work of people like Paul Gay at the Peninsula Institute of TAFE.

In the 1998-99 federal budget, an additional $13 million has been provided by the coalition to assist many more students to find employment or to receive the support of mentors for up to a year. Amazingly, the New South Wales Labor government has declined to participate in this worthwhile federal government initiative. In New South Wales, the ALP has decided that parents and students will be denied access to this much needed program through New South Wales secondary schools.

The federal government's full service schools initiative for students at risk also attracts $22.6 million. This full service schools program helps students who are at risk of not completing year 12 or who are dysfunctional in the educational environment to continue with their studies. It remains undisputed that a young person's chances of obtaining ongoing sustainable employment rise if they are able to complete year 12. Local secondary colleges like Mount Erin and Monterey have recognised this fact and, with the support of their local school communities, federal and state governments, and generous private sector sponsors, have implemented excellent programs like newstart and connections respectively.

The coalition government now has a national literacy plan up and running. All states and territories have agreed to a national plan for literacy. This is an important area in that it is ensuring that young people have the core competencies that will enable them to make the transition to the workplace and to take advantage of some of the opportunities available to them as they approach adulthood and their life in the work force. The new apprenticeship access program will help 1,900 students to access further training through apprenticeships and traineeships. The coalition is an enabler when it comes to education. Many government and non-government secondary schools are seriously taking up the flexibility and options available to them and are delivering an educational program that is responsive to the needs of parents and students.

The motion before us implies that there has been a mass drift away from mixed gender public secondary colleges. This is not borne out by the facts. While enrolment in non-Catholic independent schools has lately increased by 2.5 per cent, Catholic school enrolments have increased by about 0.7 per cent and in government schools enrolments have increased by 0.3 per cent. It is a matter of the share of the growth going to these different sectors of the education system.

Changes in enrolments can be due to many factors. Some independent schools in Melbourne, such as John Paul College in Frankston and Padua College in Mornington, are coeducational. Others have chosen, as Peninsula Grammar in Mount Eliza has recently, to admit females after many years of being boys schools. Toorak Ladies College in my electorate retains a strong tradition of catering for single-sex students.

There is no discernible push from parents for a change in the arrangements applying to government secondary schools in terms of genders and how they are catered for. Certainly, the level of competition to obtain a place at Melbourne High for boys or MacRob for girls remains very high. Many families choose to pursue this opportunity for a student place if that is their choice.

The motion suggests that differential funding of schools should be encouraged to bring about further change. Why? Why pick favourites amongst government secondary schools and imply that governments again know what is better for students than parents do? Why favour a particular type, structure or complexion of government school? Surely it is what the secondary school does to prepare young people for their futures that is important, not what they are called or what they look like.

The coalition approach is to support school communities which identify opportunities to better respond to the needs of parents and students with specific funding for programs like VET, jobs pathway, full service schools and the like. On top of increases in per student funding across all sectors, the government is supporting specific strategies to address areas where the traditional education system is not delivering the best outcomes for students. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was quite amazed by the previous speaker, the member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), saying that all in the garden is rosy. I do not believe it. He must be in one little centralised part of Australia where everything falls into place—and I find that hard to believe.

speech.para: I am delighted to be able to speak on the motion moved by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) regarding public high schools and to place on the official record my deep appreciation for the wonderful work happening in those schools, despite the enormous restrictions and inadequate funding which the honourable member for Port Adelaide alluded to.

Contrary to public perceptions and as often said in statements made by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), the public high school system, despite inadequate funding, is providing real educational opportunities for our young students, but not the best they deserve and certainly not what they desperately need. To have the flexibility within the public secondary school system to provide a range of schools is, in my mind, vital if we are to provide students within the system with the very best options for their education.

This flexibility can only occur if the schools themselves have the total support of the department and its officers responsible for the supervision of the school and the financial capacity to resource the needs of the staff and the students in those schools. By flexibility, I mean that educational learning opportunities are not restrained by having to necessarily operate within the confines of the four walls of the school, and that the schools themselves can put in place as comprehensive and as wide-ranging subject electives as possible. I think this is not happening, despite what the honourable member for Dunkley has said.

Practices ranging through one single-sex school and one technical high school and a plethora of standard high schools and district high schools have been in place with little change for the past 40 years in my state of Tasmania. It is all very well to advocate a comprehensive and far-reaching change to operations within the public secondary school system, but unless there is a complete rethinking by departments of funding allocated to these schools, we will continue to dream.

That schools can incorporate the flexibility they see as vital to ensure that not only are retention rates raised and maintained but also the students and, just as importantly, their parents can see a real link developing between schools and industry is vital, in my mind. Secondary schools in my electorate—schools once considered to be bastions of conservatism as far as curriculum is concerned—have not waited around for the departmental mind-set to change. Rather, they have attempted to address the appalling retention rates by introducing into their curriculum the flexibility and relevance which I mentioned previously.

Dover District High School in my electorate is one such school. Implementation of its aquaculture course, linked into the nearby world-class aquaculture industry, has forced the school to rethink the format of the school structure. It has altered the minds of the community and has seen a dramatic and far-reaching increase in the school's retention rate in years 10, 11 and 12. Importantly too, it has enabled some students to undertake studies at a tertiary level, which was unheard of 10 years ago, and enabled others, more importantly, to enter the local work force in the aquaculture industry.

Similar exciting and different options are happening nearby in Geeveston and Woodbridge district high schools and Hobart, Rosny and Elizabeth colleges which provide years 11 and 12 education. An even newer and just as exciting option is under way in Huonville under an organisation called CETCH which links the secondary schools in the Huon and the senior secondary colleges and TAFE colleges in Hobart with industries operating in the Huon Valley. This imaginative and revolutionary format of educational opportunities has, as I said, forced schools, the community and industry to seriously look at the options that are available to senior secondary students and students in high schools.

As the member for Port Adelaide alluded to, it is about a mind-set, a flexibility and a wide range that is available. Despite what the honourable member for Dunkley said, this is not happening in Australia. Unless it does happen, we are not going to be a productive society and we are not going to be able to provide our young people who enter school in years 7 to 12 with the opportunities and the educational opportunities that are vital if we are to be a productive society. I compliment the member for Port Adelaide for raising this issue and hope that governments do respond to the concerns raised by members in this House today.

talk.start.para: —The debate that has been brought on by the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) is an interesting one. I take pride in the fact that I have the opportunity to make a contribution to it. I am on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, much the same as the good member. In the time that we have been travelling around doing various inquiries, I must say that it has been a wonderful education.

speech.para: As far as the motion is concerned, I have not had personal representations from parents or students who have said our current school structure is failing our youth. I understand where the member is coming from, but I wanted to make that point. What I have had is a lot of parents saying that they have had major concerns about the curriculum and, in some ways, the system that the students of this great nation have had to work under. In particular, a lot of parents have said to me that they have genuine concerns in relation to numeracy and literacy. I am well aware that the member for Port Adelaide mentioned that during his opening comments, and I congratulate him for that.

It is absolutely important that we as a government and the states have a close look at the curriculum and put more emphasis on the things that are really important to students who are trying to find work—that is, the three R's of reading, writing and arithmetic. Further to that, the other thing that a lot of parents have spoken to me about is capital upgrades within the schools. In my electorate of Capricornia this federal coalition government has put a lot of money into not only the public system but also the private school system. In fact, it runs into the millions of dollars. Emmaus College, the CTCs, quite a lot of the grammar schools and so forth have all done extremely well out of this government, particularly in relation to capital upgrades and funding. The people in my electorate, particularly the students and the youth, are very happy with the amount of money that this government has put into them.

I find it a shame that the Labor Party in their term of government would not recognise the importance of the private schooling system. They did not want to recognise it. They did not put sufficient funding into it. Private schools have been calling out for a long time. Something I would like to make the private schooling system aware of is that this government has listened. It understands your problems and has delivered. There is also the amount of money that the federal coalition government has put into Catholic education. Those schools are very happy. It has gone a long way to assisting them.

School to work is a great initiative. I think it needs to be developed somewhat, and the sooner the better. The ability to be able to give a youth going to school in today's environment, whether it be in the late years of grades 10, 11 or 12, access to vocational trades and to be able to leave school and start an apprenticeship and then possibly go back and do mandatory subjects like maths and English would be of great benefit to the youth. It is something that I think needs to be significantly developed.

I look at my own existence, particularly in relation to my schooling. I finished school halfway through grade 11 and started my apprenticeship as a fitter and turner. Obviously I could not quit school and go to TAFE or something like that. You could, but I wanted to try to go as far through my high school secondary education as I could. If there was the opportunity for youth to be able to get better teaching in relation to that vocational work, it would be a wonderful and great initiative.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

debate.para: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: —In last Friday's papers we were treated to the interesting news that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had admitted in a letter to the Sydney Airport Forum that his government would not be able to implement the aircraft noise sharing promises he made prior to the last federal election. Further still, in that same revealing letter the Prime Minister made a concerted effort to wriggle out of the targets for aircraft movements set under the Kingsford-Smith Airport's long-term operating plan, or LTOP as it is referred to. While observers may think that the Prime Minister's admission of failure is a cause for concern solely among residents living in the vicinity of Mascot and in Sydney's inner suburbs, I can tell members of both sides of the House that it is not a confidence builder either for those of us in western Sydney who are living with the prospect of a 24-hour international airport being built on our doorsteps.

speech.para: Just as this government has made many promises regarding aircraft noise around Kingsford Smith and has set various targets concerning LTOP over the past two years, we have heard many statements and seen plenty of commitments given regarding Badgerys Creek airport. Just as we have seen the Prime Minister break his promises on Kingsford Smith, we are certain to see the Prime Minister walk away from his commitments on Badgerys Creek. We had the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, and soon to be ex-member for Hume, in this House saying:
The draft EIS completely dispels the concerns that many of us had when we came into office in regard to Badgerys Creek airport. The draft EIS clearly indicates that Badgerys Creek is a superior site.
We had the current Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) put out a press release which stated:
The government welcomes a widespread and detailed debate about the proposed airport development . . .
And promised:
Each and every submission, as well as the Auditor's findings, will be taken into account in the preparation of the final EIS as further work continues on the key second airport issues . . .

If the Prime Minister's promises on Kingsford Smith cannot be trusted, why should people now believe these commitments on Badgerys Creek? Why should the western Sydney residents action group, the Communities Against an Airport in Western Sydney, believe what government representatives tell them when they meet with them in Canberra this Wednesday? Why should the members of the Western Sydney Alliance, the major anti-Badgerys Creek airport group in western Sydney with a membership made up of 10 major councils in the region, believe the government when they come down to Canberra to meet MPs in a week's time?

What faith can they have that the Prime Minister will stand by the promises he and his ministers have made on Badgerys Creek? They can have very little faith at all. The Prime Minister knows this. He knows that his government cannot, or will not, meet the commitments he and his ministers have given on Badgerys Creek. That is why he is preparing for the next stage in his plan to build the airport—the advertising snow job. The Prime Minister wants to dip into his little bag of tricks and pull a swiftie on the people of western Sydney by organising an advertising campaign that will apparently teach us to love the idea of having jumbo jets flying over our roofs 24 hours a day. He is hoping it is going to be a bit like that Peter Sellers movie, and we all remember it, Dr Strangelove—`How I learned to stop worrying and,' in this case, `love the airport.'

The government is paying $500,000 to a PR company by the name of Cosway to organise a media campaign designed to—and I will read directly from the Department of Transport and Regional Development's budget portfolio paper:
balance the public debate through the provision of factual material and the correction of any inaccuracies in the media.

Knowing the Howard government's form on airports, and particularly the EIS process on Badgerys Creek, when we read the words `balance the public debate', we should actually interpret that to mean `bury the public debate'.

What the government really intends to do with this advertising campaign is spend half a million dollars burying the independent auditor's report on the Badgerys Creek EIS that found the document's analysis and investigation—using their words—as being `deficient', `limited' and `ambiguous'. This government means to bury the auditor's findings on the EIS—and I again quote their words:

As a result of . . . time and cost constraints imposed by the Department of Transport and Regional Development, the draft EIS generally does not go into the degree of detail that could reasonably be expected for such a proposal.

The government means to bury the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority's report on the Badgerys Creek EIS that found that it `did not demonstrate the real impacts on the community for any particular site option'. It means to bury the opinion of the head of the New South Wales EPA, Mr Neil Shepherd, who has said:
There are serious deficiencies in the Commonwealth's approach and the information available and the EPA is concerned about the implications of this development for air quality in the Sydney basin.

This government hopes to bury the opinion of a senior minister in the Howard government, the former New South Wales Premier, the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), who said, `I remain to be convinced about any of the proposals for Badgerys Creek.' And, most importantly, this government means to bury the opinions of almost every state and federal MP in western Sydney, be they Labor, Liberal or otherwise, and the concerns of the people they represent. There are members in this House representing western Sydney who are against Badgerys Creek airport. They know, along with the majority of their constituents, what building a 24-hour international airport in their region will mean to the quality of life of people in the area.

The people of western Sydney know they cannot trust the Prime Minister when he says he will provide a transparent EIS, because he has shown them, by breaking his promises on Kingsford Smith, that to do so is folly in the extreme. They know they cannot trust the assertions of the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development when he says that Badgerys Creek is the perfect place to build an international airport, because expert opinion is now saying otherwise. We cannot trust the current minister when he says that public debate is welcomed on Badgerys Creek and that all voices will be listened to on the subject, when he is about to embark on a public relations campaign that aims to smother those same voices.

The people do not trust this government on Badgerys Creek, so the government is going to spend half a million dollars trying to hoodwink them. That is the agenda we are starting to see develop before our very eyes. Rather than spend $500,000 on a giant confidence trick to get western Sydney residents to accept Badgerys Creek, the federal government should be addressing the inadequacies of its EIS report. It should be looking at alternative options for building Sydney's second airport, such as Goulburn—locations that have real promise and are supported by the local community. That is the only way this government is going to earn the trust and confidence of western Sydney residents. Until then, we will view the public statements and actions of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development in regard to Badgerys Creek through increasingly jaundiced and distrustful eyes.

We need to take action now. We cannot defer, as the Minister for Transport and Regional Development keeps telling us, a decision on Badgerys Creek until after the election because they will not have their assessments done before December. We know that is inaccurate. We also know in western Sydney that you cannot say to people, `We're going to provide you with a public relations campaign that's going to tell you how wonderful this airport is,' when the people are saying, `How can you tell us that when you can't even answer the obvious questions that we have asked over the development of the EIS?'

We need to have action taken in this regard and we need to have that action taken now. We should not have to wait continually for community groups to come down here and try to put pressure on either government or non-government members. We should, as a government and an opposition, stand up and say that Badgerys Creek is not wanted by the people in western Sydney and reject the airport accordingly. I have always said it was the wrong decision. I have heard arguments for and against it, but I have stood firm since 1986. But, more importantly, the whole area has changed. The expectations of the community in general have changed over that period of time, and I believe government has to take that on board as well. What has been designated and designed in a particular way years ago is not what is needed now. When we are going to spend the amount of money that will be required to build a second international airport, it must be there for many years to come. It should not be placed in an area which will face the same concerns and problems as are being experienced now with Kingsford Smith.

As I said, this government came into office in March 1996 with great promises to the people who lived in that area. We have already seen the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) resign from the Liberal government because promises were not kept in regard to his constituents in the seat of Lowe. We have already seen continued debate occur in this parliament and outside this parliament over the inadequacies of the EIS and the consultation process. What we do not need now is more money spent by this government out of this particular budget where it clearly shows $300,000 now to be allocated on top of the $200,000 that is about to be spent to tell the people they are going to get that airport and they are going to learn to love it. People are not stupid. They never have been stupid, and they will not take this type of solution as an answer to what they perceive to be a very important problem.

I call on the government and members representing those constituents—I am pleased the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) is here today—to take the message loud and clear that the government must act now with the interests of the community at heart and, more importantly, start listening to the citizens that they represent and to make sure that message gets to them very clearly and very succinctly. We do not want a snow job. What we want is action and some honesty from the government, and we want a decision made that is going to be not for next year or the year after but for the building of our community for the next 50 or 100 years, and that means saying no to Badgerys Creek.

talk.start.para: —I have spent the break in the sittings talking to the people in my electorate. They are not concerned about single issues. They are not concerned about how much money Aboriginal organisations are getting, or how much anti-airport groups are getting, or how much women's organisations or ethnic groups or child-care centres or unions are getting. They resent the fact that funding for organisations to deal with single issues is being eaten up by administration costs and that money is never getting to the coalface of the problem. In other words, their taxes are being spent not to resolve problems but to exacerbate them.

speech.para: Taxation on the mainstream people of Lindsay, the battlers that I spoke about in my first speech in this House, has got to a level where they are no longer able to sustain their own welfare, their own ability to look after themselves, as well as all the other demands on government coffers. Their taxes have gone up in the recent Labor state budget—yet again Labor. Taxes went up enormously in that budget and in the previous government between 1993 and 1996 taxes also went up. It has reached a desperate situation in Lindsay. They are working harder and they feel they are not getting ahead. In a few moments I will actually prove that that is the case.

Taxation reached such a stage under the last government that people's ability to look after themselves and their individual family's needs has been compromised, and they want that addressed before any consideration is given to other interests further up Maslow's hierarchy of needs. They are concerned that they will not be able to pay off their mortgage in their lifetime. They will not be able to provide for their old age any better than someone who has never worked. They are afraid that their children will have an even harder time paying off a home and securing their old age. There is an overwhelming feeling that we are no longer the lucky country, that we have lost the lucky country. That is why it is such an aberration that Labor has walked away from the tax reform debate and has refused to be involved in some meaningful dialogue where we could come to some bipartisan resolution of tax reform in this country.

This loss of faith by mainstream Australia is very distressing for me, because I have travelled the world many times, much more than most people in my electorate, and I know that Australia is better than any other country in the world. I am a migrant to Australia, and I have found this country to be welcoming and full of opportunity. Although I have been delighted to experience a whole bunch of other cultures in my world travels, I will always return to Australia because this is where I have had the greatest opportunity and reached my fullest potential. I have a vision for our nation where my children will have more opportunities than I have had. I have had more opportunities than my parents had, and Australia has given me that.

Our kids will have a variety of jobs to choose from in the new world. Over 60 per cent of the kids in year 3 today will be working in industries that we do not even know about yet or have not even described. The pace of change will not slow down. Change is not a nasty word; change is inevitable, and change generally is an endeavour by mankind to improve a situation. There will be a variety of lifestyles for them to choose from. There will be a number of contributions they can make to society and to the community. I believe passionately in this. As a leader, I must make sure that the people who have lost heart in my electorate also believe it too.

The barrier to believing in Australia as the land of opportunity that I have described is that in your everyday existence in Lindsay working harder seems to be sending you backwards. With assistance from Glen Thorp, who has designed a computer program called the Family Income Analyser, I can now show for each individual family in Lindsay what their optimal income is. It is real proof that working harder does send you backwards, or at least there are diminishing rewards the harder you work and the higher income you procure.

A fellow who is earning $12.55 an hour in a factory will earn $24,800 a year for a 38-hour week. If his wife is at home with three children aged three, six and nine, he will see in his hand as disposable income just on $33,904 a year. However, if things are tough and he does some overtime to get his family ahead, and he really chases the dollar and works 68 hours a week—puts in an extra 30 hours a week—his salary will jump by $17,100 a year to $41,900, but he will only see an extra $1,757 per year; that is, $33 a week for working an extra 30 hours a week. There are many people in my electorate who are in that situation, who are only seeing 10c in the dollar for every dollar that they earn. His wife would be better off telling him to stay home at the weekend and spend time with his children and value that time rather than trying to improve the family's circumstances.

Another constituent of mine, who is a single mother of one and whose ex-husband has remained unemployed to avoid paying child support, would be entitled to $15,229 from social security payments, including rent assistance, if she did not work. She is currently working for $24,000 a year or $460 a week, and she is paying $150 in rent. She is around $167 a week better off than if she was not working. If she increases her efforts so that she earns more money and earns another $3,600 a year, she will see $144 of that—that is, $2 a week for an extra $3,600 a year.

Just say her ex-husband had remarried, had two more children aged under five, and he was paying $60 maintenance a week. On a salary of $26,000 he would see around $30,008 a year for earning that extra money. If he went out and chased the dollar, did some overtime and earned an extra $2,700 a year, he would see $1. If he did not work, he would receive up to $27,027 a year in social security payments or just $57 a week less than if he was working. The incentive for the battlers of Lindsay, whom I came in here to represent, has been destroyed under this current taxation system. It is wrong and it needs to be repaired. It is an absolute disgrace that the opposition will not even enter into this debate or come to some bipartisan situation where we can offer relief for people in this situation.

I found plenty more examples, when sitting outside Centrelink one day last week, where families are better off accepting some sort of subsidy from their employer, such as the use of a car, to cut their family expenses and leave their income lower rather than taking an increase in income, paying the extra taxes and losing various benefits. For the employer, it would be more cost effective to do that too. That is something that the government must be aware of—that this new computer program will be used by human resources managers and employers and everyone to look at that optimum area in which to pay staff.

There is no doubt that our taxation system is broken. It is dragging the chain on all the pay-as-you-earn middle class in my electorate. It needs to be addressed. It is Labor's system that it created during its 13 years in government. We have not had much of an opportunity, given the situation in the Senate, to make much of an impact on it, but it needs a drastic overhaul in all areas of the three three-inch volumes of the tax legislation. The complexity of it astounds most accountants and, if you have seen the recent Tax Pack, it is a challenge to most PAYE wage earners.

As leaders we must open up communications with our electorates to inform them that we are aware of their struggle, that we are aware that they need assistance in the mortgage and child-raising phases of their lives, and that we are prepared to do something about it. There is much to be done. Whilst the opposition goes on about one-issue wonders, the mainstream is moving away to other areas, and they have lost faith in them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I originally wrote this speech before the Queensland state election, but since then I am even more convinced that my grievance is well justified. I have a grievance on the impact the current economic situation is having on regional Australia. There are huge problems developing as services become centralised, as government departments become privatised and as technology reaches only those who can afford it.

speech.para: Out in regional Australia that leaves the young and the old, the struggling small business and the small farmer without many of the support and advice systems they had before to allow them to survive. Banks have gone, schools and hospitals are closing, policemen are covering bigger and bigger areas, the health system is under huge stress as funds are removed and doctors are leaving country towns and are not being replaced. Employment services are hardly available anyway.

Our telephone system is inadequate, and it is vital that we provide telecommunication access for rural, regional and remote Australia comparable with what is available to people in the cities. The community service obligation allows for only a standard telephone service, and this needs to be upgraded to a standard telecommunications access. Whether the new satellite service recently launched will cover these concerns remains to be seen. There is a cost attached to new technology that was not attached to the roll-out of the standard telephone.

Australia Post is also under threat of being deregulated, which could lead to the bush paying more than the cities for standard postal services. This would also put at risk other services such as GiroPost, banking, bill paying and tax return filing. Add this to the push for Australia to be in front on the breakdown of tariffs, the removal of bounties and the growing imports that are competing with our own products and we have an economy indicating that thousands will be out of a form of personally developed income by the end of this century.

Country Australia will also be deeply affected if tax reform includes a goods and services tax, as many people exist on very low incomes and there is no equity in an overall consumption tax. There is also the very real problem of the paperwork involved in the collection of such a tax for small business and, no matter what is done to try to stem this work, it will be onerous for the family businesses and those who employ only a few people.

All this means that the regional and country areas are under incredible pressure. My grievance is that there is no need for all this. There are alternatives. What is the point of a $2.7 billion surplus when the community is hurting? The interesting thing is that some of the economic commentators are now questioning the role Australia is playing in developing free trade. By allowing imports to flow into Australia to open markets elsewhere, it is succeeding in putting extraordinary pressure on many of our high quality value added products.

The report I spoke to earlier today, Adjusting to agricultural trade reform, recognises that globalisation and liberalisation of trade are occurring outside our control. It also stated that, despite liberalisation, an overwhelming number of trade barriers continue to impede market access.

I can only quote again from the report on the pork industry where the Pork Council pointed out that reciprocal market access conditions should be negotiated with countries seeking access to Australia. Denmark is seeking unimpeded access to the Australian market, but Australian firms wishing to export there would face quotas and tariffs of up to $3,000 per tonne. The pork industry is being decimated by the current importing of Canadian and Danish pork. Prices for pigs nationwide are the lowest in three decades. An average piggery of 100 sows producing 32 pigs a week is losing $1,120 per week. Some producers are having difficulty selling pigs at any price and some producers are being forced to destroy stock.

The primary cause of this crisis is the unimpeded access for potentially unlimited quantities of subsidised pork. This is tanta mount to dumping and, with the current Asian crisis, it could well mean that many of the exporters will look around for a suitable country to dump their surplus. Australia will be caught because of its open trade policy and because it has very little protection.

Salmon is another product being tied up in Australia's push for open markets at any cost. And it is at any cost. The cost could well be the health and productiveness of the industry. Fish diseases are very easily introduced to water environments and could well wipe out an industry. Why are we even considering allowing uncooked product to enter our shores?

There are many other primary products as well as those that have been value added—for example, paper—that are being affected by the open slather trading that is occurring in Australia. This will mean the loss of thousands of jobs. We already have the situation in Burnie and, if left without some intervention, there will be no reason why the rest of the pulp making industry will remain in Australia, let alone Tasmania. We need to have a more careful approach to tariff breakdowns to allow our companies to compete on the same level as others on the same market playing field.

Take a region like Tasmania. It is on the periphery of the periphery, where there is little opportunity to influence the national economic direction. It will be put under great pressures. A non-performing state government coupled with a panicking federal government along with trade liberalisation is decimating our economy in Tasmania. The world trade negotiations tend to aim towards the big primary producers—red meat, wool and grain—and this can be at the expense of the smaller, niche market based products such as honey and salmon. We have good products and many of those are on the edge of the export market, yet we are unable to compete on the same level because of the many impediments in place.

Australia can take steps to improve liberalisation, but it does not have to take the lead on much of the trade agenda. There should be means by which talks can allow change to happen more appropriately. The government has a role to play in these changes. It must increase awareness among primary producers and exporters of the advantages of networks which can aggregate supply and coordinate marketing in a strategic way. Government also needs to play a role in the restructuring of industries to ensure that those who are going through the process of change are not put at a financial disadvantage to the bigger players in the field. At the moment, pork producers play a very much second-fiddle role to the red meat industry in the export area and in the domestic market. They have had very little assistance at all and pigs are now being slaughtered because of the imports.

It makes me very angry to see people on the land—the very people I grew up with, worked with and shared a life with—being rubbed out of existence. The Queensland people said the same thing: `It is not fair to treat us like this.' Simplistic and unrealistic solutions are not the answer. Those who lead cannot just voice the problem. They must be prepared to have the answers or work through with the people to find the answers.

The government can intervene and use its financial powers to assist the industry to change, to maintain those who are restructuring, to encourage jobs to be created and to keep services in small towns to assist and enable those who are facing change to continue. Economic rationalism is only good for the big end of town. It does nothing for small business and nothing for the people trying to survive in difficult economic times. There are a lot of opportunities out there. Let us help our communities to develop them.

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the member for Lyons (Mr Adams), mentioned regional and rural Australia, and it is quite timely that my address is linked to that part of Australia which I come from as well. I will have a different approach to this topic because I believe that regional Australia has very positive opportunities currently and this will be very much so in the future.

speech.para: In Australia we have 148 House of Representative seats. Of those, 62 are defined by the Australian Electoral Commission as rural or regional in nature. The government currently holds 49 of those seats and 15 of those were picked up at the last election. Non-metropolitan Australia generates about 80 per cent of our export income, and these figures will vary from year to year and will be debated depending on where you draw the lines on the map. We know we have the perennial industries of agriculture and mining, but increasingly we have processed product coming out of regional Australia and contributing to our export income. So no-one would question the contribution of regional Australia in economic terms as well as social and cultural terms. I think it is very important in this discussion that we see the urban-rural situation as the interdependent connection—that is, production from rural and regional Australia contributes to the standard of living in metropolitan Australia and vice versa.

If we think about that 80 per cent of export income for a minute or two, it makes a very powerful point at a time when we have a government that is quite determined to encourage exports and to manage the national debt and certainly the Commonwealth debt where it has the most control. By its policy of balanced budgets and the charter of budget honesty, the government can bring an effect which keeps maximum downward pressure on interest rates. We have the right environment in Australia to maximise export income from regional Australia.

As of 1 July, we will have a new allowance known as the youth allowance, which has been much requested. It is one of the longstanding requests that I am very pleased, as part of this government, to be able to deliver. The replacement of Austudy, particularly with rent relief, is a significant step forward for rural and regional students who have to study away from home. The taxpayer—and this gets back to the interdependent nature of our economy and people—is going to pick up a little more of the extra costs of education where students have to study away from home. No-one would question in this day and age the importance of higher education and developing the skills of our people.

The previous speaker talked about the telephone service and said that there was some potential threat. The reality in my electorate is that we have never had greater opportunities to improve our telecommunications and communications generally. With the networking the nation or regional telecommunications infrastructure fund, we have opportunities now to bring our communications system much more up to the standard that metropolitan people are used to—and we are already putting them into effect. Be it the Internet, a telecentre, a range of data provision services or whatever it might be, there is a very great determination to bring that service up to an appropriate standard.

I mention here the Eyre Regional Development Board and the work that it has been doing with consultants and the local community to look at preparing a submission to bring that part of Australia, which no-one would suggest at the moment is up to speed, up to speed over the next few years to the advantage and enhancement of the economy and the region at large. I congratulate those people. It is a great encouragement to see the government giving the support that it is in these policies, which would never have happened under the opposition.

In terms of access to regional health, I commend the government for the departments of rural health, which are very much part of our national scene in regional centres now as the focus is brought to bear on those issues which need greater attention in regional health delivery. There is one in my electorate—in Whyalla at the University of South Australia. With some very able people driving that process, I am very confident that we will see improvements to the range of choices and service delivery in the health of regional Australians.

The issue of access to Medicare funding is something that I have always had a particular interest in. The reality is that regional people do not access Medicare in the same way that metropolitan people do. It is important to recognise—we may need to look further at this—that the amount of money that is spent on regional health through Medicare per individual is not as great as it is in the metropolitan services. There may be a range of reasons for that, but we need to be very aware—I know this government is, particularly through its departments of rural health—that regional people do not access health services and, therefore, the cost is not the same as it is in metropolitan Australia.

The issue of native title has been much debated in this place. The thing that I want to reinforce here again today in my grievance is that not very often do you hear the opposition, or many metropolitan people for that matter, acknowledge that the greatest burden, just about the whole burden, of native title—the inconvenience, the reality of native title—falls on regional people, particularly on a small minority of people. I cannot express my frustration deeply enough for two groups of regional people—that is, Aboriginal people and those people who have native title claims on their properties. The tragedy of this issue is that we see something like $200 million going into legal activities which give no benefit to those on whose land the claim is made and absolutely no benefit to those for whom the claim is allegedly made. If that is not an absolute lesson in nonsense and stupidity, I do not know what is in this country.

I want to briefly finish today on the issue of fuel excise. Someone did some figures a long time ago which suggested that regional Australians pay about twice as much per head in excise as urban Australians. They pay 2c per litre on top of that for leaded fuel. The only place in Australia where leaded fuel is really an issue for the environment, as I understand it, is in the metropolitan areas. Not only do we in regional Australia pay a lot more for our fuel because of fuel excise but also we pay twice as much—it would vary in individual circumstances—and we have this insult of the extra 2c for leaded fuel where there is no real impact on our environment. So this fuel excise impacts not only on our daily lives in terms of domestic activity but on everything we do in business, mining and agriculture. This fuel excise may have been justified 30 or 40 years ago for a road repair fund, but it has moved on and now funds everything. The greatest inequity is that it falls doubly on regional Australians. That, I believe, is a matter for serious grievance.

talk.start.para: —It seems that regional Australia is the issue in the grievance debate today. I follow from both the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) in expressing my concern about the state of play in rural and regional Australia. There will be an election pretty soon and there will be plenty of issues confronting the next government. There could be none more important amongst them than the issue of unemployment. I was reading an address delivered by Cheryl Kernot recently. She was talking about the state of unemployment in this country, the question of job security and, just as importantly, the terrible situation we have in this country where middle aged Australians are suddenly finding that they are redundant or no longer required in the work force. She quoted Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who once said, `No country, however rich, can afford to waste its human resources. Demoralisation caused by vast unemployment is our greatest extravagance. Morally, it is the greatest menace to our social order.'

speech.para: I believe that the root of most of our social problems in the late 1990s has its base in unemployment. There is little doubt that unemployment remains the greatest challenge facing this country. Despite the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) travelled the width and breadth of this country prior to the last federal election bleating about the state of unemployment in this country and in particular youth unemployment, the Prime Minister has now run up the white flag on the employment front. His budget basically tells us that unemployment in this country hovers around the rate at which it was when he came into office. He has basically given up. There is no hope for the unemployed in this country.

talk.start.para: —It's lower.

—The honourable member for Sturt interjects and says that it is lower. We can argue about 0.001 of a decimal point if he likes, but the reality is that struc tural unemployment in this country is in no better position now than it was when John Howard first came to office.

speech.para: In the Hunter region the unemployment rate is now about one percentage point higher than it was when the Prime Minister came into office. At around 10 per cent, it is more than two per cent higher than the national average. In the Cessnock local government area, the subregion that I want to focus on today, the unemployment rate is more like 12 per cent or probably higher, depending on whose figures you listen to. Indeed, it has been put at as high as 15 per cent. The youth unemployment rate in the Cessnock local government area has been estimated to be in excess of 30 per cent. The unemployment rate in the Hunter and, in particular, the Cessnock LGA continues to be a major issue.

Since 1994 about 1,400 coalminers have lost their jobs in the northern district. Almost 70 per cent of them lost their jobs in coalmines within the Hunter electorate. About 900 of those job losses occurred in the last two years. Unfortunately, there are many more retrenchments to come because of the state of the world coal price market.

A very large share of those who have lost their jobs in the coalmining industry reside in my electorate of Hunter. A very large share of them reside in the Cessnock local government area. The situation in that LGA is at crisis point. The Cessnock LGA and the communities that make it up were basically founded on coal. The area once boasted more than 30 coalmines. Its last closed recently.

We used to have a strong textile and clothing industry, but it has now moved on. Our kids used to go to BHP and Comsteel and those major industries in Newcastle for their apprenticeships, but those opportunities are very few these days. They also went to the coalmines for their apprenticeships. Those opportunities are also very limited.

Our great white hope, tourism, now faces new challenges due to the Asian economic downturn. There could be no area more worthy of targeting in terms of special Commonwealth assistance than the Cessnock local government area. What I am asking today is for the Prime Minister to look at that area and consider very seriously the implementation of a special economic adjustment package for the Cessnock local government area in particular.

Plenty of scope exists for assistance from the Commonwealth. It is the only level of government with the resources available to it to undertake it, and it should do so. Cessnock is far from dead.
