With the Badgerys Creek site, which is landlocked, there is a 360-degree problem. No matter which option you go for—A, B or C—planes will be flying over residential area soon after take-off.

There is particularly strong opposition to this airport from the rank and file members of the ALP in western Sydney. In correspondence sent to people who had made submissions on the Badgerys Creek EIS, from Minister Vaile's office, an attempt was made to imply that the federal ALP members in western Sydney supported the building of Badgerys Creek airport. Nothing could be further from the truth. The minister's letter conveniently ignored the speeches made by the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), the member for Chifley (Mr Price) and myself concerning the airport.

The letter also ignored the strong stand taken by state ALP members of parliament opposing the airport. More importantly, the letter ignored the grassroots opposition to this airport by ALP branch members, federal electorate councils and a recent regional assembly decision also opposing the airport. There is no more significant block of community expression of opposition to this airport than the ALP block in western Sydney. The major political parties will ignore the views of the residents of western Sydney on the issue of Sydney's second international airport at their peril.

talk.start.para: —Pauline Hanson, the member for Oxley, says that her One Nation Party is different from all the other political parties. In this respect at least she is absolutely right, as the Sun-Herald newspaper revealed on Sunday. Whatever faults the existing parties have, at least they are all internal democracies. In the Liberal Party, for instance—my own party—members elect delegates to state council, the state council elects office-bearers and elects an executive to take responsibility for the affairs of the party. It is a democracy because every member has a share, however small, in the democratic decision making process of the party.

speech.para: The member for Oxley says that she is listening to the people, that she is the only true democrat amongst all the mere politicians that make up this parliament. However, an examination of the One Nation Party's internal structure shows that the member for Oxley believes in democracy but not just yet. She believes in democracy but only for other people. Pauline Hanson's political party is not a political party as such, but a company. It is not a democracy, but a business. It does not have thousands of members: it just has three directors—the member for Oxley, David Oldfield and David Ettridge.

Like the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), I do not believe in personal attacks on my colleagues, however misguided they might be. But I do think that the people of Australia have a right to know—any of those who are tempted to support the One Nation Party—that it is not a democratic party they might be tempted to support but, in fact, a private company with just three directors running it and they are responsible to no-one but themselves. The people of Australia who might be tempted to support the One Nation Party need to know that every time they give One Nation money they are not giving it to a democratic organisation which they control: they are giving it to a private company run by just three people.

They should also know—and again I am indebted to the Sun-Herald for this information—that every dollar they give to One Nation means 12.5c given to the pocket of David Ettridge. David Ettridge, as it turns out, is operating on the same basis as Terry Bourke, the brother of Brian Burke, the former Premier of Western Australia, operated; only at least Terry Burke's money went to the Labor Party which was democratically controlled by its members.

Then there is the question of the public funding of $500,000 due to One Nation as a result of its Queensland election vote. This $500,000 presumably is not going into the hands of the party itself; it is going into the hands of the three people who control that party—Hanson, Oldfield and Ettridge. The people of Australia need to ask the question: is what they really want that public funding should go not to democratic parties but to private companies controlled by just three people?

I think it is time that explanations were demanded from the member for Oxley. What does she intend to do with the taxpayers' money to which her party is entitled? I seek from the member for Oxley an absolute and categoric assurance that none of that taxpayers' money will end up in the hands of David Ettridge. I seek a further assurance that none of that taxpayers' money will be used to fund the personal expenses of her staff.

It is a very strange political party which trots out a member of a politician's staff to speak on behalf of the party. In this country, we have a tradition that politicians should speak for themselves. Sure, staff advise them, but at the end of the day they speak for themselves and they take responsibility for their words. But, with One Nation, you might vote for Pauline Hanson but you actually get David Oldfield who not only writes the words but also increasingly is saying them. This is a deeply un-Australian development.

As someone who knows David Oldfield's capacity to look after No. 1, I warn the member for Oxley not to put herself in the hands of two old diving buddies who go back much further with each other than they do with her. I make this prediction that David Oldfield will use One Nation to try to get himself elected to the Senate and then he will seek to become the leader of One Nation in form as well as in substance, and that would be a very dangerous and damaging development for this country.

talk.start.para: —Having received an honourable mention in Paul Sheehan's odious polemic Among the Barbarians , I rise to comment on the recent rise of the racist One Nation Party. It is worth thinking about why now? Why has racial intolerance and bigotry moved at this time from the lunatic fringe to the centre stage of our national politics?

speech.para: The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has from time to time portrayed the rise of One Nation as a backlash against political correctness. Over 13 years of government, Labor consistently gave leadership on the issue of immigration and racial tolerance. We proclaimed our nation's multicultural diversity. We championed our engagement with Asia and reconciliation with indigenous Australians. We did not hesitate to confront bigotry, prejudice and racism. If that was political correctness, then we were very proud of it. It was our leadership, coupled with Australia's great reserves of tolerance and decency, which for so long kept racial intolerance and bigotry off the centre stage of our political life.

Of course, others took a different position. Any explanation of the rise of One Nation must include the preparation of Australia's political ground by years of coalition sloganeering about the supposed evils of political correctness, the alleged failures of multiculturalism and the thinly veiled pandering to the darker undercurrents of Australian society. It was John Howard who played the race card in 1988 with his advocacy of an anti-Asian immigration policy—something with which One Nation is now only too happy to exploit in its search for political legitimacy. John Howard paid the political price in 1988 when so many people recoiled from what they saw as the start of a reversion to the White Australia of old.

It was only after he had made extraordinary efforts to reinvent himself, to assure Australians that he was a new John Howard, that people were prepared to give him a second chance. The old adage that a leopard cannot change its spots certainly applies to the Prime Minister. No analysis of One Nation's rise can fail to highlight the Prime Minister's calculated refusal to confront Pauline Hanson and to confront the fundamental threat her party represents to Australia's future. When Pauline Hanson first attacked Asian immigration and the rights of indigenous Australians, John Howard applauded what he declared to be an end to political correctness. All along he has consistently sent her supporters carefully coded messages of sympathy, encouragement and support.

No-one can ignore the vital role of coalition preference votes in translating support for One Nation into parliamentary representation in Queensland. John Howard's persistent refusal to put One Nation last gave them political legitimacy they could never have gained otherwise. He did not just fail to treat this political cancer; he nurtured it and allowed it to grow. One Nation would have won fewer, if indeed any, seats in Queensland if the coalition had followed Labor's example in putting One Nation last on its how-to-vote cards.

Yesterday, the Prime Minister grudgingly said he would put One Nation last in the seat of Bennelong. But, even now, he refuses to give the leadership required to ensure that all elements of his government put One Nation last. Even now he has nothing of substance to say about his coalition partners. This is nothing more than sending a message to Liberal voters in our cities, while Tim Fischer and the Nationals hold to their strategy of extending preferences to One Nation in the bush.

It is John Howard who is comfortable and relaxed about seeing the balance of power in the Australian Senate transferred from Brian Harradine to One Nation. Even with a half Senate election, we face the prospect of being held hostage for six years by a racist fringe with all the poisonous consequences that will mean for our national life. It does not worry John Howard—not at all. He is relaxed and comfortable about seeing Australia's politics swing back to the past he, after all, always wanted us to be in: the Australia of the 1950s, the exclusive society of old.

The good news is that, whatever happens, John Howard's leadership is finished. Well may he eke out what I think is an increasingly paranoid existence in the Lodge, but no carefully coded messages to One Nation can revive his prospects. He has lost all his moral authority, and it is only a matter of time before he moves from the political stage. But it is those of us who are left behind, those of us who will have to deal with the morning after his office, who will have the task ahead of us—those of us who will pay the penalty for this racist tango.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the need for a realistic look at the transport facilities available in my electorate of Gilmore. The declaration of main road 92, the Shoalhaven Highway, as a road of national importance is recognition of the need for the transport corridors on the South Coast to be opened up further. The local community has been fighting for this for 20 years and now it has taken the guts and cooperation of the three tiers of government to see that this is achieved.

speech.para: The Shoalhaven City Council has been proactive in its efforts to get this road upgraded and it has been supported by the declaration of the road as a RONI. However, the Princes Highway, which travels the length of Gilmore, is also in need of urgent funding, particularly in black spot areas such as north Kiama, the Minnamurra bends, Ulladulla, south Kiama and Nowra. However, the federal Labor Party has already signalled its intention not to provide black spot funding and not to fund roads of national importance.

In fact, the opposition transport spokesman described the funding of main road 92 as a `retrograde step'. He said, `It's just a gravel road,' and gave no consideration to the importance of this `gravel road' for the communities of the South Coast. This was despite the upgrade of main road 92 meeting the Labor Party's platform in regard to environmental concerns and alternative routes in cases of emergency.

Obviously, Labor will not fund the upgrade of main road 92 and Labor will once again ignore the Gilmore community, as it did for the 13 years prior to the election of the Howard government. It is no wonder that the Minnamurra bends have also been ignored by Labor. The road is the responsibility of the state government, and the New South Wales Minister for Roads has only given it medium-term priority for upgrading, despite the horrific accidents along the road which have claimed the lives of many local residents and visitors for many years.

Even my predecessor, the then Labor member for Gilmore, Peter Knott, laid the blame for the upgrade of the north Kiama bends squarely at the feet of Bob Carr when he issued a card-writing campaign. What did Mr Knott have to say? He said:
Dear Bob,

We are writing to you about the horrible traffic bottleneck that occurs at Kiama every weekend. We've waited 10 years for the RTA to build the North Kiama Bypass! Can the Carr Labor Government please be decisive and give us leadership in solving this problem?

What has been the response of the Carr Labor government? Roadworks on the Kiama bends have been declared only of medium-term importance and it appears that the state government will do nothing for at least the next six to 10 years. That is what a Labor government thinks of the needs of the local community.

Some months ago, the NRMA completed a study of the Princes Highway which concluded that several areas required immediate upgrading. I wrote to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) in May seeking his support for making the Princes Highway south of Sydney to the New South Wales-Victorian border a road of national importance. I also requested that consideration be given to allocating funding from the black spots program to the areas mentioned as particularly dangerous, including the Kiama bends.

It is interesting to note that neither of these categories of funding will be supported by a Labor government. Not only are the transport corridors of the community ignored, but so too are the dangerous sections of road known as black spots. Some 12 months ago I invited representatives from the Kiama Council to meet with senior advisers to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. The result of that meeting—which included the Kiama state member, the Kiama Council mayor, the deputy mayor, the general manager and the engineer—was to wait for the outcome of the studies by the state government.

I understand that those studies are still being finalised, yet the deputy mayor of Kiama—now the Labor candidate for Gilmore—is campaigning for the federal government to fund the upgrade of the road through the Federation Fund. Even the New South Wales Premier, Mr Bob Carr, did not include the Minnamurra bends on his wish list for the Federation Fund. Again, the Labor Party does not support the upgrade of the Minnamurra bends and will not fund it.

I have already sent the Labor candidate a copy of the application for federation funds so that she can follow the normal procedure to apply like any other Australian and like members of the Gilmore community who are putting forward proposals. Rather than go through normal channels, Labor candidates are playing politics with the needs of the local community. What a shame that the Labor candidate does not pay attention to the fact that it was her delegation which put the federal government involvement in the road on hold until her Labor Party mates in the state government accepted their responsibility for the road.

Labor will not fund the upgrade of main road 92. Labor will not fund the upgrade of the Minnamurra bends, even if that road is made a road of national importance, and now Labor wants to see the funds set aside to help communities celebrate the centenary of Federation put in to cover the lack of leadership, responsibility and accountability of the current state Labor government.

To start yet another petition, just like the former Labor member for Gilmore did, shows that the Labor candidate believes that the people of Kiama are naive and will fall for such a political stunt. Actions such as the commitment by this federal government to fund the upgrade of main road 92, to fund the roads of national importance, to fund black spot areas, speak louder than the empty words of rhetoric from Labor.

talk.start.para: —On a number of occasions in this House there have been calls on the government to establish an Australian embassy in Zagreb, Croatia. Most recently, a private member's motion was moved in May by the member for Moore (Mr Filing) and seconded very ably by my colleague at the table, the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), calling on the government to give active consideration to establishing such a facility in Croatia and making the very obvious point that there was a very significant gap in Australian representation overseas. Government members in this chamber, on that occasion, as they have on other occasions, opposed that particular proposition.

speech.para: The proposition comes back before the House through this medium because I have received—courtesy of the ALP's outstanding candidate in the seat of McMillan, Christian Zahra—a petition organised by the Gippsland Croatian Association calling for the government to establish an embassy to the Republic of Croatia. Unfortunately, the petition is not in a form suitable for formal presentation to the House, so I take this opportunity to speak on the matter.

Obviously and self-evidently, south-eastern Europe is not in Australia's prime sphere of strategic interest, but there are nonetheless vital interests for Australia in that region. It is the place of origin of tens of thousands of Australian citizens, and an estimated 10,000 Australian citizens are presently resident in Croatia. However, in that situation, to service that very significant social and cultural need, we only have one very under-resourced, overworked honorary consul to meet the vast array of duties that are required by the level of representation that the Croatian Australian community demands.

The needs not only relate to the Republic of Croatia but also to the adjoining Republic of Slovenia and to Bosnia-Herzegovina. It is an area from which tens of thousands of people have migrated to Australia. In that region of south-eastern Europe, the government continues to neglect the important functions that can be performed by an upgraded and enhanced Australian diplomatic and consular presence.

Because of its social and cultural contacts and because it is the place of origin for so many of our citizens, Australia has an oppor tunity to act as an honest broker from time to time and to play a role in resolving some of the outstanding issues that afflict that part of the world. Our failure to provide diplomatic representation there is a significant missed opportunity.

A very significant range of economic opportunities is also provided in that particular part of south-eastern Europe which Australia is simply not in a position to adequately explore, given the absence of effective representation, and we therefore place ourselves behind our competitors in that region in a situation where, hopefully, in the context of peace settlements emerging over time, rapid economic growth can be achieved.

Australian interests in that part of Europe are represented from the very charming city of Vienna. I can understand why some of our diplomats might well enjoy life in Vienna. There are important functions to carry out in Vienna, not least because it is the home of the International Atomic Energy Agency. Nonetheless, that does not diminish the significant inconvenience and the significant missed opportunities that arise from Australia not taking up the opportunity from the call from the Australian-Croatian community for the government to advance this issue. The only reason in opposition advanced by government speakers on the occasion in May was the question of cost. The reality is that Australia is missing significant opportunities which are not costed into this. Australia does maintain representation in some places which, I would suggest, are somewhat less important to us socially and culturally than south-eastern Europe.

There is also a very important area of grievance in the Croatian community in Australia in relation to the failure of this government to adequately pursue social security agreements and health agreements with Croatia. Australia does have a significant number of social security agreements, but nowhere near enough, and a smaller number of international health agreements. These agreements are vital, particularly in aging communities, to ensure that Australian citizens, through their circumstances, are treated equally with other citizens. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Just before question time this afternoon the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) made another of the sleazy statements for which the ALP has achieved some renown. He asserted that at a recent Liberal Party branch meeting in my electorate there was division among members over where One Nation should be placed on the ballot.

speech.para: I know that the member for Wills and Labor members on the other side of the Hume Highway are taking a keen interest in the electorate of Deakin. If the member for Wills had bothered to spend $1.30 of his own money, he would have read in yesterday's Sunday Age in an article by Gabrielle Costa that `I want to put One Nation last even though it could cost me some votes'. If his intelligence were more reliable, he would know that I have expressed grave concern about the activities of far right groups in the area and my fears about the citizens of Deakin being unsuspectingly swayed by these extremists.

If the member for Wills were to make an honest assessment, he would admit that I have always supported a multicultural Australia. If he had any integrity at all, he would admit that I have promoted harmony among various groups of different ethnic backgrounds by attempting to bring them together for purposes a lot more honourable than the branch stacking by those opposite. If he had done half the research normally expected of a shadow parliamentary secretary, he would know that I have successfully argued for the establishment of a migrant resource centre in the eastern suburbs, an area long neglected by the former Labor government.

But honesty and integrity have little place in today's Labor Party. With the whiff of an election in the air, they are happily following the Pied Piper down the gutter. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) retains a seat in this place only because of the preference deal he did with Australians Against Further Immigration at the last election. In his early days as leader, he compounded his hypocrisy by presiding over the Lindsay by-election, nodding and winking when his old mate Ross Free preferenced that same party over the Liberals. I have the how-to-vote card of Ross Free in front of me as evidence of that.

I know Kim Beazley is not a racist, but he has a shameful record of placing politics above principle when he believes it to be advantageous. He has done so on this issue, as he has done with his two-faced stance on tax reform. By contrast, many coalition MPs have stood up for the principles of fairness. They made it clear as I have made it clear: One Nation will be last on the ticket. I would not care to phrase my attitude as the Sunday Age did—that is, content to risk my seat—but I make no bones about my opposition to One Nation's tawdry stance on racial issues and their pathetic, simplistic approach to employment and industry development policies.

These are dangerous ideas expressed by a party that is controlled by those who dwell in the shadows of our society. To the people of Deakin who are seeing these ultra right-wing elements such as the National Action group and those individuals typically associated with the Ku Klux Klan moving to Ringwood in Melbourne's east, I say be careful. But One Nation's ideas are not new ideas. They have been heard before. It seems as if some of the survivors of the self-instigated class warfare long ago have now emerged from their cave espousing old militant Labor beliefs.

The member for Wills is playing the game of demagogues. He criticises the coalition from the security of his safe seat yet is loath to speak out directly against One Nation because he perceives some political advantage in his silence. The true test of political courage with One Nation preferences is by those of us who live on the electoral knife edge.

The member for Wills could have no understanding of the Liberal Party, where debate is encouraged and not stifled, where ideas have primacy over timeworn mantras, and where the interests of all Australians are worth more than the votes of special interest groups.

For the record, there was no letter from Premier Kennett even though he has spoken out strongly against One Nation. Finally, there were no threats emanating from the meeting. The Liberal members of Deakin have no sympathy for One Nation or One Nation's views, but they are all very keen to fight and to once again expose the fraud that Labor continues to perpetrate on the Australian people. As usual the ALP has it wrong, but they have never been guilty of letting the truth interfere with a good story.

talk.start.para: —I, like nearly every member in this House, abhor the racial agenda of One Nation and many of the things it stands for. It is a really sad state of affairs in this country when people's frustrations should be centred on that party because they see a lack of representation of their frustrations in the existing party system. It would be quite wrong to write off One Nation's result in Queensland as an aberration. The Queensland election result showed that One Nation is a lightning rod for that frustration and the insecurity that is now out there, particularly in regional parts of Australia.

speech.para: When this government came to power it was quick to point out that the former Labor government had been guilty—and so it was, largely—of political correctness. But for the last decade in this country anybody who has spoken out on the economic agenda, the trade agenda particularly, of government and the world trade liberalisation program has been accused of questioning the economic correctness that has been out there in the marketplace. This has particularly stuck in the craw of people like the pig producers out there who do not want to be told they are inefficient, that they have no future if they do not export. They have a very efficient industry, as have others in the rural trade.

I instance the industry in my own electorate that I alluded to in the trade minority report delivered to parliament today, Challenge Implements Pty Ltd in Orange, which, but for the want of a five per cent protection, are likely to go out the back door because they are suddenly faced with huge economies of scale from multinational importers of farming equipment. They have a strong research and innovation program that means a lot for that area. An age-old family business and 30 to 40 long-term employees are likely to hit the wall, be wiped off the face of the earth, for the want of a five per cent protection.

I think this government is barking up the wrong tree when it believes native title is so essential to its future at the polls. That was not what the Queensland election was about; it was about the need for some lightning rod for that frustration—to send a strong message to the parliament and to the political parties that there needs to be a reassessment of their priorities. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) now speaks of freehold in the same breath as the rights of pastoralists. Native title is nothing, and will be nothing, whatever happens in the Senate, without the right to negotiate for those who have cleared that very high threshold hurdle.

The media should take a very strong look at itself over its role and its handling of the Hanson phenomenon. It accepted recently on the front page of the Herald that Ms Hanson was responsible for the backflip in the pig industry assistance package, when in fact you and I know that this package had been worked up over several months and was due for announcement some time that week. It says a lot for the very clever manipulation of the media by the organisation behind One Nation.

The media has been less than scrupulous in its dealings throughout the last couple of years. The publication of articles in the paper at the weekend I would suspect as being not of her own writ. Not enough attempt has been made, as the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) alluded to earlier tonight, to make the leader of One Nation stand up and be answerable for her own policies instead of letting other shadowy figures become the mouthpiece.

The member for Warringah says that the agenda of One Nation is an Oldfield and Ettridge agenda, and it certainly seems to be that way. Let the leader stand up here and defend herself more and more. Who is funding this organisation? It has only a modest amount of money on the public record but seems to have unlimited resources elsewhere.

talk.start.para: —It wouldn't have anything to do with firearms, would it?

—I wonder. I appeal to the electorate to examine the ability of One Nation to deliver anything meaningful. They should look, if they need to—and I suggest they do at this stage in the party system history—at broad based Independents, particularly, say, Robert Wilson in the seat of Parkes, rather than wasting their vote. Look at a man with a lot of background who can deliver something of substance. (Time expired)

—I rise tonight to highlight the success of the work for the dole scheme, particularly in my electorate of Robertson. I am very proud to announce that I have the largest work for the dole scheme anywhere in New South Wales. This scheme is operated by Gosford City Council and has approximately 120 participants. The managing agents of that scheme are Personal Attention and Associates, a group in my electorate that I know well and who are well respected.

speech.para: The work for the dole scheme is not just a training scheme. It is about giving people a new start, a new hope in life and getting them jobs. One of the problems we have with our work for the dole scheme in Gosford is the fact that we keep losing participants, not because they wander off dissatisfied but because they get full-time employment and they leave the scheme.

I have two totally unsolicited letters here from two participants in this scheme. I would like to read them into the Hansard tonight. The first letter is from Raelene Nicholls of Umina Beach. She wrote:
To All Staff,

I am writing to say thank you to each and every staff member for not only doing your job, but for being so genuinely caring and always enthusiastically helping people with the hard task of job seeking.

I, being a mother of three small children, had left the workforce for maternal reasons, had been unemployed for a period of two years. I decided to return to the workforce not realising how difficult a task I had set out, I soon became depressed and found I needed help. I decided to volunteer—
yes, to `volunteer'—
for the `Work for the Dole' scheme to give myself experience going to work and leaving my children, as well as learning new skills to help me better my chances of obtaining a job.
Little did I know at the time that the staff actually seeked possible employment positions for their recruits and then arrange an interview if suitable.
In my case I was suitable for the position informed about and got the job. I am thoroughly enjoying my Customer Service position at Brumbys Bakery and have been for nine (9) weeks.
I would also like to add a special, THANKS, to Chris Hoare, my supervisor at Osborne Ave, Umina (work for the dole site).
That is the new youth facility centre that we are constructing under that work for the dole scheme. The letter continues:
Chris taught me to regain confidence not only in myself but also in others, with his always positive outlook and good will. My only regret about my volunteer work was having to part.
Thank You again for changing my life.
Yours wholeheartedly,
Raelene Nicholls
The second letter is from Darryl Ward, also from Umina. He wrote:
To all the Staff of Personal Attraction,

All the thanks in the world go to you for all the help & new skills I received from you. You gave me & others on the dole the chance to get back in to the swing of working. This project also gave me a new attitude and the right motivation to start looking for work again

I work at the Osborne Ave site for 5 mths. In this time I learned how to correctly use power tools, hand tools & wood, to make all types of obstacles for the youth of the coast. (Chris, watch out for that shovel)

To all the projects on the coast you're doing a great job & you've got an excellent team behind you in your team leaders. Elizabeth & all the office staff, O! who can forget `Dave' and `Chris'. And the one that shines all the time with all the energy of the world at her feet `Kay'.
Good Luck To All of You,
Thankyou,
Darryl

Those are just two letters from two very enthusiastic participants in the work for the dole scheme. I have been to the Osborne Avenue site. I have been to a number of other sites throughout the Gosford shire where the work for the dole scheme and its participants are working. They are an enthusiastic bunch who are being trained by a professional group of trainers. They are creating for themselves a work ethic and a team building spirit that I have not seen at any other training scheme anywhere on the Central Coast. They are allowing people to get back into the work force, to get control of their lives again and to start rebuilding.

I look forward to the expansion of the work for the dole scheme, and I would hope that many thousands of other young people will have an opportunity throughout Australia to participate in the work for the dole scheme, which, unlike some of the previous government's training schemes, is not just recycling people but finding them jobs and giving them a chance to regain their lives. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I join with the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) in expressing some concern about revelations over the weekend in regard to the internal operations of One Nation. As the member for Warringah has quite clearly pointed out to this House, there are all the indications of a very undemocratic structure within that organisation. It appears that essentially we are talking about a company with ownership by three political operators—one of whom is elected to this House. I was also concerned about aspects of the articles over the weekend which indicate that internally members in different sections of the organisation are restricted in their contact with other elements within the party.

speech.para: On a local front, I was interested to note that the candidate standing against me in the seat of Reid was selected before a meeting occurred within that electorate. He was elected at a meeting of people in another electorate. So there are very strong questions about the structure of this organisation. I think the Australian people would be increasingly concerned as to where taxpayer finance is going in regard to electoral funding. As the member pointed out, if one looks at the amount of money they have obtained on the public record, one will see that there seems to be a great discrepancy between their ability to fund their operations and what they reveal in regard to finance.

What we have here is a structure which has come up in the context of very grave concern by the Australian electorate about politicians and whether they are listening to them, about long-term employment prospects, et cetera, ad nauseam. But the conduit for that concern, the conduit for that worry about the future of this country, is very questionable.

I want to turn to one of the groups that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) particularly concentrates upon—the Aboriginal community in this country. I was provoked today in regard to receiving one of those vote-a-grams which talked about equity in this country. Basically, that line of argument in regard to Aboriginal people stems from the comments made by the member for Oxley in her maiden speech in this House.

It is worth putting on the record again—and I know that the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has been a pacemaker on this—some of the facts about Aboriginality in this country. Only 45 per cent of Aboriginal men reach 65 years of age compared with 80 per cent of the rest of this country's population. Only 54 per cent of their women reach 65 years of age compared with 90 per cent of non-Aboriginals. For Aboriginal children, the incidence of pneumonia is 80 times higher than for any other Australian. Thirty-four per cent of Aboriginal communities have water supply levels below accepted national guidelines. Forty-five per cent have insufficient water supply to meet their needs over the next five years.

Forty-five of the 99 deaths in custody investigated by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody were people taken from their parents as children. People try to say that it was not of any relevance, that it was not of any moment that people were taken from their parents, yet we are seeing a clear correlation between deaths in custody and the taking of those people. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody completed its final report in 1991. It investigated 99 cases of deaths in custody. Since then there have been another 100. Young Aborigines are held in juvenile detention centres at a rate almost 50 times higher than other Australians.

It is about time the Australian electorate realised that for all our ingrained concerns about race issues in this country, these factors—their health, their incarceration, their mortality, et cetera—are not because they are Aboriginal, are not because of their blood, are not because of their genetics. This is simply a fact that we see around the world. If I go to Brazil and I have a look at the fate of the Amazonian Indians, I will find the same situation—totally unrelated to the Australian Aboriginals. They are marginalised people who have had their country seized and essentially characterised by these unfortunate aspects of life expectancy.

In Colombia, we see oil companies essentially raping the country at the moment. There have been articles about them. If we go to Japan, the Ainu will have the same characteristics because of the way in which they are marginalised in their society. If the member for Oxley and those around her talk about equity for people in this country, it is about time they recognised the clear deprivation of Aboriginal people in this country.

talk.start.para: —Last Wednesday, with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), I was privileged to witness a tree planting service at the Keith Payne VC Park at Stafford in my electorate of Lilley. The deeds of the bravest Australian war heroes have been permanently implanted in the hearts and minds of the Lilley residents with this tree planting ceremony, honouring all 96 Australian Victoria Cross recipients.

speech.para: Local war hero and VC winner Keith Payne and South Australian Ted Kenna attended the ceremony and presented 96 memorial plaques and trees to honour the Australian brave VC recipients. The year 7 students from Stafford Heights and the Stafford state schools have been given the responsibility for carrying on the memory of their assigned heroes. They have researched the lives of the VC recipi ents, care for the memorial trees and wear their name badges on Remembrance Day. Last June I informed the House that I was part of a special commemorative service at the Keith Payne Park and saw the unveiling of the plaques to honour those men and women who received the VC in the Boer War, World War I, World War II and the Vietnam War.
The Stafford Heights school captain, Matthew Butterworth, said:
The tree memorial at Keith Payne Park has transformed the park into a special place that will hold long lasting memories for future generations.

I feel greatly honoured to be in the company of Mr Payne and Mr Kenna today. I researched the history of the Victoria Cross and read accounts of the Vietnam War, and I realise how extremely tough and frightening it would be to be a soldier at war.

I cannot imagine fully what it would have been like for all our soldiers who fought for our country, but Australia would not be the free country it is today if these men and women had not left home and family to risk their lives for us.
The Stafford Heights school captain, Peter Baumann, went on to say:
At a recent Stafford Heights ANZAC Day parade, our Principal, Mr Murray, reminded us that our links with our war veterans could be lost as our diggers passed this life.

This is a concern to every one of us. These badges will be proudly displayed in our school foyer and will be proudly received by future students. In this way we will continue honouring our VC recipients.

It is important to us to never forget the wars that our soldiers fought in because they fought for our country. So we think that the community links programme is a great concept for Stafford and Stafford Heights communities. We'd like to thank the RSL for giving us this opportunity.
The Stafford State School captain, Jesse Parkes, said:
I am lucky to live in this country and enjoy the sort of freedom of which other countries can only dream of.

These men fought so hard for freedom that we take for granted. We are here today to remind ourselves of their sacrifices. Without the sacrifices of their lives, their family, and their youth, the freedom we enjoy today would not exist. To live in our own country without freedom would be unbearable.
We hope by reading about their endeavours it will lead us to loyalty to our nation. The Victoria Cross recipients showed the ultimate loyalty by fighting for their nation.
Finally, we are joining into a partnership with the RSL to look after Keith Payne Park. This is showing a public spiritedness by working together to give something to the public to use and enjoy.
Stafford State School's other representative was Emily Carnell, and she spoke about Edward Kenna's bravery against the Japanese. She said:
It is because of people like Mr Kenna that we live in a free country today. Mr Kenna, I thank you.

This park stands for service to the community; it will serve the community just as the Victoria Cross recipients served their country in defence of freedom. This park is a place in which people can spend their leisure hours partaking in social and recreational activities. Such activities might not have been possible without the effort of these great men.

As the federal member for Lilley, I would like to thank Mr Ken Ryley, the Kedron Wavell RSL sub-branch, Brisbane City councillor Jim Wilding and the students and teachers of the Stafford and Stafford Heights state schools for making the day such a success.

talk.start.para: —It is an interesting situation that we have this evening with extra time for adjournment speeches as a consequence of what appears to be some slack time in government business. It is an interesting situation given that the government is now looking at about 1½ weeks more of sitting before, one presumes, they are going to call an early election. I ask myself as a member of this place, `What on earth has happened to their organisation that they are not able to organise their business efficiently enough to be able to occupy the time with government business before that time runs out?'

speech.para: I want to talk tonight about tax reform—a matter that many people are speaking about—and deal with three issues in particular: one is the reform of Commonwealth-State fiscal relations, a very important matter in relation to Western Australia; another is the question of reforming substantially the problem that occurs where moderate income earners now find themselves, because of fiscal drag or inflation, pushed into higher marginal tax rates through no fault of their own and are now paying, in many instances, tax rates that once were devised as part of our progressive tax system for people in higher income brackets; and the third is the opportunity of abolishing the wholesale sales tax and replacing it with a broad-based tax that will not increase the number of tax collectors in the country or, for that matter, increase the burdensome red tape and compliance for small businesses.

Finally, I want to look at some means whereby PAYE taxpayers are relieved of their obligation to submit a tax return each year for a pittance in terms of a rebate. It obviously causes an enormous amount of work on their part, and an enormous amount of effort is expended on an exercise which, in effect, delivers only a very small net proceed to the Australian Taxation Office.

I want to start with vertical fiscal imbalance. Western Australian taxpayers have been cheated of $778 million over the past five years in the effective return of their wealth generation from the Australian Commonwealth proceeds. This means that in my electorate the residents of Kinross still do not have a senior high school. It means that the residents of Mindarie still have to make do with a primary school campus—an experiment, a model one, a temporary campus—which probably would be considered to be a slum school if it were anywhere else.

It also means that residents in Clarkson, Merriwa, Butler and elsewhere are unable to access effective efficient public transport sufficiently able to give them the flexibility to work and to entertain themselves or to enjoy the benefits of Perth life through effective travel. Also, in the Joondalup police district my constituents have, in effect, a police to citizen ratio four times inferior to areas elsewhere in the state.

Looking at tax reform, we need to flatten marginal rates so that the people who are being dragged into higher rates of tax under our progressive tax system are not paying rates of tax that should be applicable to people on higher incomes. We also need to introduce a retail services tax to replace the wholesale sales tax—a tax that is levied at the point of delivery or sale for services or goods but with a similar system for the preceding processes to that of the wholesale sales tax. In other words, those involved in production or in manufacture have an exemption number that allows them to claim an exemption when purchasing goods and services that apply in the production process.

Obviously, this government has not been able to deliver on its promise of reducing compliance and red tape by 50 per cent in its first term of government. In actual fact, that has increased. One of the reasons I am concerned about the government's tax reform proposals, when we get to see them, is that it is very hard to believe that any government would in effect be able to deliver a simplified tax system that reduces the paperwork and compliance for small businesses. For anyone on the coalition side to claim that more paperwork is going to be better for small business because it will introduce discipline to their paperwork is highly insulting and gratuitous in its scope. I can only urge the coalition to think very carefully before trying to pass off some sort of tax reform process on that basis. The reform of Australia's tax system is long overdue. All I can do is urge the coalition to think very carefully before it brings it forward. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —A couple of weeks ago, I attended a Green Corps graduation in the Blue Mountains. The 10 young graduates had been employed for six months at Wentworth Falls working with Intelife, Mission Employment. They had been involved in a range of hands-on environmental experiences—bush regeneration in a disused quarry site, protection of sensitive areas, design and construction of pathways, erosion control and the design and establishment of permaculture gardens.

speech.para: The graduation was an encouraging event. The enthusiasm of the 10 young people was quite contagious and their positive comments were very instructive. It was obvious that the six months had been a very valuable experi ence for them. Not only did it provide valuable work experience; it gave them a sense of achievement. They could point their finger at the results of their work and proudly say, `I did that.' It was a valuable esteem-raising program. For them all, it was a unique educational experience with the opportunity to learn a range of practical skills in environmental work. Some even spoke of it providing a new sense of direction and a clearer idea of further courses of study or careers to pursue.

I put the success of that particular project down to two main things. Firstly, Green Corps is an excellent program. This government's allocation of $42 million over three years to employ 3,500 17- to 20-year-olds in this hands-on work is evidence of a dual commitment—a commitment to assisting our young people into valuable work and a commitment to environmental restoration. Already under this program 1,200 young people have participated in Green Corps programs. They have planted half a million trees, collected over 250 kilograms of native seed, built more than 100 kilometres of walking track and constructed over 100 kilometres of fencing. The Green Corps program is producing valuable, tangible environmental results. Last week's graduation was in fact the second in the mountains. Another project in my electorate—Hands Across the Catchment—is currently under way and another group is ready to begin in a month's time.

Secondly, the success was also a credit to Intelife, a branch of Mission Employment. The Intelife project is an exciting one which, as I indicated, is involved in restoring a disused quarry site in Wentworth Falls in the Blue Mountains. In so doing, it is revegetating what was a highly degraded area, thus stopping further erosion and the resulting sedimentation of local streams. It is also building a demonstration centre for environmentally sustainable technology. This includes solar powered, mud brick buildings, a natural sewage treatment process and a water reuse system. It involves the establishment of permaculture gardens. Further, it involves the construction of accommodation for disadvantaged young people.

The Intelife project is a unique and exciting project. But the greatest asset of Intelife is its team—a group of caring, capable and committed leaders who provide quality educational experiences, valuable environmental work and strong personal support for the young people involved. The teary farewell speeches at the graduation were clear evidence of the close bonds formed and the esteem the graduates showed for the team leaders. I am pleased that this government has been able to assist Intelife in its work in the local environment and its valuable work with local young people.

talk.start.para: —This evening I would like to make a few remarks about the passing of a stalwart of the Salvation Army in my area, Mr John Wright. His funeral was held today and, unfortunately, I was unable to be there owing to today's parliamentary sittings. His passing merits special mention because of his extraordinary experience and, I might say, because of the fact that he made such a tremendous contribution to the work of the Salvation Army in my district.

speech.para: John Wright was in his professional career an engineer, a successful man. Unfortunately, alcoholism became part of his life and he entered a hopeless phase of his life during which time his circumstances deteriorated to such an extent that he found himself in a bad state. At some stage, the work of the Salvation Army became a revelation to him and he turned his life around. John Wright then became a Salvation Army officer and he became a stalwart of the Salvation Army bridge program. He became an advocate of drug rehabilitation and counselling, and in particular an advocate in relation to alcoholism and drug abuse, to young people and to others alike. John Wright suffered in his final months terribly from his illness, and his work in the Salvation Army in our district will be sorely missed. I pass on my condolences to his widow, Eileen.

The Salvation Army in my district performs a tremendous range of functions to the com munity. It is one of the few organisations that truly merits the respect and support of a vast number of our community. The Salvation Army is readily identifiable as one of those organisations that seems to be always present, always ready, always helpful in situations. Whether it be because someone has passed into a desperate phase in their life and needs assistance, whether it be because of a civil disaster or an emergency, whether it be the provision of emergency relief for families who are encountering stressful conditions or who are financially or otherwise disadvantaged, whether it be the provision of a range of youth and other activities and, more recently in my electorate's case, whether it be the provision of employment services, the Salvation Army is second to none in providing a sustained, consistent and available service to all in the community.

I would like to commend those who assisted in the recent Red Shield Appeal in my district to raise a large amount of money once again to help the work of the Salvation Army. I might say that, in my electorate at the Heathridge Centre and the Merriwa Centre, there is a shortage of resources to provide essential services to families and emergency provisions to families who have found themselves in dire straits or who are unable to provide for themselves in the short term.

In particular I would like to commend the work of Captain Neil Venables and Lieutenant Paul Hakely, who are in charge of the Heathridge Centre and the Merriwa Centre respectively. The Heathridge and Merriwa centres provide those services to an area containing one of the greatest concentrations of families raising young children in our country. Demographically, my electorate contains a majority of people below the age of 21. I am sure that that is not the case in other electorates.

The state director of Red Shield Appeal, Arthur Jackson, is also to be commended for his efforts during the 1998 Red Shield Appeal. It is a fundraising exercise that enjoys the confidence and support of a large number of people in the community. I commend the work of the Salvation Army to all, and urge those in my electorate to support the 1999 appeal as much as possible to help make sure that we raise those valuable funds to ensure that the Salvation Army is able to continue providing those valuable services throughout our community.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to talk about some exciting things going on in the electorate of Dunkley concerning our young people. Like a number of other members that have spoken in this adjournment debate already, I was fortunate to attend the graduation ceremony for a number of work for the dole programs over the last fortnight. The really exciting thing about that is to see how the young people involved in those programs have seized the opportunity provided to them through the work for the dole program and made something quite substantial of it, not only for themselves but also for the local community. We launched the retail index that the young people involved in the work for the dole program had produced for Karingal, Frankston and Mornington, which was an important initiative given the large section of our economy that the retailing sector represents. That was a chance for young people to develop their marketing skills, to get involved with the local retailers, to present their ideas and information, to plan a project, to produce a document and to deal with its circulation. It was a worthwhile outcome and an example of how the local communities got right behind the work for the dole program to develop projects that are relevant to the local community and that bring young people in touch with employers in areas of genuine job opportunity.

speech.para: We also celebrated the completion of the natural environment enhancement project. There were a number of reserve areas in the Dunkley electorate where these young people seized the opportunity. They got involved in weed eradication, in transforming what was just bush into rather special parkland for the local community and in developing and improving the walking trail for the Sweetwater Creek Reserve, which I am quite familiar with. We witnessed in the last week a graduation ceremony that recognised those contributions. The graduation ceremony itself was planned and organised by those young people. They were very proud of what they had done, and they deserved to be.

The really exciting thing was that more than half the people involved in the program have had very positive outcomes. There has been quite a turnover of participants in the program as young people have gained employment and as they have thought about their future lives and decided that they would pursue further studies either through a TAFE course or by returning to secondary education. They are really important outcomes for those young people. They are back on track, they are back making a useful plan for their lives and looking forward to a brighter future because of the work for the dole program. I congratulate all those young people. It is really exciting to see young people taking advantage of this opportunity and working with a local provider, Skillsplus, which is now a very significant participant in the jobs network.

There are other things that have been going on for the youth of the Dunkley community. The youth health service that Dr Martin and the youth health forum in Frankston have been developing is something that I discussed with Dr Martin and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) during his recent visit to the Dunkley electorate. All are very interested in this project as a way of making sure that young people can gain access to the health services, counselling and support that they need so that they can get on with their lives. Many of the local general practitioners are also the family doctors and young people are a little reluctant to talk with the family doctor about some of their health concerns or troubles in their lives for fear of that information perhaps finding its way back to the family.

Finally, I want to talk about the Padua College, a secondary school in the Dunkley electorate run by the Catholic education system. We celebrated 100 years of that college in the last fortnight. There was a eucharist service—a very exciting occasion. Again, we saw on that occasion all the splen dour of young people applying their skills and a desire to make a go of their lives.
A lot of exciting things are happening for the young people of Dunkley. It is something that I am happy to be a part of and that I will continue to encourage within the electorate.

talk.start.para: —Over the last few days, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has made much of the Labor Party's decision to put the One Nation Party last on all its ballot tickets. He has continually paraded himself before the television cameras and in this chamber, proclaiming moral rectitude and a higher moral stance in his party than in other parties in Australia because he has decided to take this in-principle decision.

speech.para: If one were completely convinced of his stance, one would find it laudable. But the Labor Party has a tradition of operating in election mode in its own best interests and setting matters of principle to one side. We saw in the Lindsay by-election, for instance, the Labor Party being prepared, in order to gain an advantage, to trade with people who are considered by some to hold racist views

It is a tragedy if there is an inconsistency amongst our leaders. It is seen by the public for what it is. If Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, wishes to raise these matters, he should be able to point to a record of his personal consistency. One cannot compare the Labor Party between leaders because I do not think that is fair. Each leader puts his own stamp on the organisation. It is up to the leaders to be consistent in their application of moral principles.

However, in the last couple of days a publication that appears to be from the Australian Labor Party has come into my hands. I wish to table it tonight and seek clarification from the Leader of the Opposition. Across the top of the page, it has `Turn your banned guns into something else.' On the left-hand side of the page there is a picture of an automatic military weapon. On the right-hand side, there is a picture of a hand filling in a ballot paper. The ballot paper has the heading `The next election.' At the top of the paper, One Nation, No. 1, has been filled in. Second on the paper is No. 2, Labor. At No. 3 is the National Party; fourth is the Liberal Party. Underneath it states `The Australian firearms payback.'

I want the Leader of the Opposition to indicate whether this is a Labor Party publication by one of the branches or part of the Labor Party organisation. There is no doubt in my mind that the only group in Australia which could gain possible advantage by a publication of this sort that appeals to the pro-gun lobby would be the Australian Labor Party.
An honourable member interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It was not produced by me. There is the envelope that it arrived in. You put it to the AFP. You can do whatever you like with it. I am going to table it here tonight. I want a denial from the Leader of the Opposition or anybody else connected with the Australian Labor Party that this is not a stunt of the Australian Labor Party in sending out two messages. There is a moral rectitude message and there is a subterranean message for those with an alternative attitude to life whom the Australian Labor Party claims are worse than scum on the earth. They are sending a message to these people saying, `The Australian Labor Party understands the principles of One Nation and the pro-gun lobby.'

speech.para: It is an outrageous publication. It has my secretary's note on it. We received it in the mail today. It is dated 19 June, and it has no name on either it or the envelope. It says `For your information', and it has a signature on it. The Australian Labor Party can have it. I am going to put it on the table, and it can do what it likes with it. I want an absolute denial that it is not playing double games in this whole process leading up to the election.

You can look at the envelope. It was posted somewhere in Victoria. You can look at it, and you can have the AFP look at it. It is a double game. If it is from the Australian Labor Party, we can understand the strength of what the Leader of the Opposition is saying. His outrage at some of the things going on in Australia will be proven fake. The Australian Labor Party is playing a double game with the people of Australia. It is encouraging the people who have banned guns to put the Australian Labor Party second on their ballot paper. People are to vote No. 1 for the One Nation Party, No. 2 for the Australian Labor Party, No. 3 for the National Party and No. 4 for the Liberal Party. I repeat that the caption states `The Australian Firearms Payback'. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have looked at the third edition of Pettifer's Parliamentary Practice . On page 559, it appears that the requirement for leave to table a document applies to ministers other than in question time, a personal explanation or the making of a ministerial statement. Accordingly, I ask whether leave is granted for the tabling of the document.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member for Mitchell did not seek leave to table the document. He indicated during the speech that he would seek leave, but he never sought leave to table the document.
—I am just saying that leave is required. The honourable member for Mitchell, therefore, is seeking leave, because he said that he was going to table it.

—The speech that we have just had delivered by the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) is an absolute disgrace. It says a lot more about the member for Mitchell than the issue which he brought up in the House tonight. Ever since the massacre at Port Arthur, the Labor Party, and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) in particular, have gone out of their way to support the Liberal and National parties' attempts to tighten the gun ownership laws. The member for Mitchell has come into this House tonight and sought to slander the Leader of the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party after we supported him in this parliament and in parliaments right across the country. It says a lot about the morality of the member for Mitchell that he would come into this House tonight and drop that bucket.

speech.para: It would be interesting to know who gave the member for Mitchell his orders to come into the House tonight and attempt to throw mud at the Leader of the Opposition and the Labor Party. That is what we would like to know. Who gave you your instructions to behave in such a low manner? Is it any wonder that they had to demote you from the whip of the Liberal Party to simply a parliamentary secretary. Actions like those portrayed tonight demonstrate why he is held in such low regard by his colleagues and us on this side of the House. The basic allegation of the member for Mitchell was that the Labor Party is playing a double game.

talk.start.para: —You always do.

—The member for Macquarie supports the member for Mitchell in his attempts to throw mud at the Labor Party after we have attempted to support the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in his gun ownership reforms. We note that the member for Macquarie is supporting the member for Mitchell in his statements in this House.

speech.para: The only party that I know is playing a double game on gun ownership is the party that has established a firearm owners branch of its political party. You tell me which party I am talking about. It is a party which has allowed a member of one of the coalition parties in the state parliament who represents an electorate not very far from the Australian Capital Territory to establish a gun owners branch of their party. Do you know which party I mean? I challenge the member for Mitchell to interject as soon as he recognises which party has been playing the double game. It is a party which has allowed one of its state members to recruit gun owners for its party so that it can seek to undermine the reforms that the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition have supported in this parliament.

The one party that has been playing a double game has been the National Party of New South Wales. It has allowed the member for Monaro, Peter Cochran, to establish a firearm owners branch of the National Party. At the most recent state conference of the National Party in Orange, those members of that branch of the National Party sought to pressure the National Party to support a watering down of the Prime Minister's tightened gun ownership laws. If the member for Mitchell wants to come into this House and point the finger at any party that is trying to play a double game in the debate on firearm ownership laws, he should not point the finger at us. He should point the finger at his own coalition party, which has established a firearm owners branch.

To come into the House tonight and to seek to slander the Leader of the Opposition after he has given bipartisan support to John Howard, the Prime Minister, in the reforms he introduced into this parliament two years ago says a great deal about the morality of the member for Mitchell and a great deal about the people who have given him instructions to come into this House tonight. Through you, Mr Speaker, we can say to the member for Mitchell that on every occasion that he seeks to come into this parliament and throw mud at the Leader of the Opposition on issues such as this we are going to hold him accountable. Every time the member for Mitchell and his supporters such as the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) come into this chamber and seek to blackguard the name of the Leader of the Opposition we are going to hold them accountable. We will put in that extra effort in their electorates to make sure that their constituents understand the morality that they bring into the Australian parliament's House of Representatives. You will be held accountable for what you did tonight and you will deserve the opprobrium that you have earned.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to make a few points on behalf of my previous colleagues in the Department of Defence who take a commission, a Queen's commission, which is a very nebulous form of employment, and on behalf of those who sign on for various periods of time in the other ranks. It has always been a very tenuous situation. I believe that in today's litigious society we should perhaps be looking towards giving our defence members a more definitive employment contract. Labor laboured on for 13 years with burgeoning litigation and did not really solve the problem.

speech.para: I will give you an example. We have a number of diabetics in the RAAF who were diagnosed as diabetics after they were employed. Some are coming very close to their DFRDB retirement period and are being discharged because they have diabetes. One man who has voluntarily left was actually the armaments officer who defused live explosives that were delivered to the base by police or civil agencies who had discovered them live. He had the responsibility of defusing them, and yet he was found to be lacking and was discharged.

It is a very one-way contract. It is at the Queen's pleasure, and there is not much that anyone can do about that. Yet the defence department can at will extend your employment. In certain circumstances, people have been kept in service, with very little compensation in some instances and in other instances quite clearly against their wishes. So it is something that we need to look at. In a recent survey, using my Family Income Analyser I worked out for a woman who happened to be married to a serving member that with her family make-up it really was not worth her husband being promoted. So we still have a way to go. I would like to see us working some way towards a very definitive employment contract for our defence personnel.

Further to that, also around my electorate, on this year's great polly peddle, I did a lot of work with youth in the area. It is quite clear to me that drug use is quite prevalent amongst many of our youth. Sadly, there are some parents who are ignorant of the extensive use of drugs by their children. They feel that they are in an awkward position to discuss the issue with their children, simply because they just do not know enough about it. They are not sure what THC is or means today. They do not know what an eccy is. They probably have a vague idea of what a bong is but certainly not how it comes in today's packaging. There are also a lot of myths about marijuana and other drug use, and parents are unable to dispel their children's perceptions of it, because they have not discussed it with their children or they do not know what their children's understanding of drug use is.

In order to combat that, I am in the process of organising an information day for parents in my electorate where they can find out about all the drugs that may be confronting their children today, get the true facts on them and open up some dialogue with their children in which they can properly direct and give their children some sort of guidance on the issue so that the children are better able to just say no.

A particularly critical time, when drug pushers target children, is when the children are moving from grade 6 into high school. As they move from being big fish in a little pond to being little fish in a big pond, they are very vulnerable to drug pushers who quite frequently today happen to be in school uniform. Parents have to know about this vulnerable stage, and they have to know what the facts are and how to discuss the issues with their children. With the support of the Panthers Leagues Club and Darren McMahon, a youth worker with a Penrith Christian church, I am looking forward to getting that seminar up and operating in Lindsay some time in September-October for the information of parents in our area.

talk.start.para: —I want to make some comments about the issues the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has tried to raise concerning the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the One Nation Party. I think that my colleague the shadow minister for health, the member for Dobell (Mr Lee) did a very good job in countering him on the guns issue, but if we are going to talk about the One Nation Party and the issue of standards and double standards, we cannot go past the tremendous double standards of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

speech.para: It is very interesting that, following what happened in Queensland, the Prime Minister was roundly condemned by all the editorials in this country for the way in which he has handled this whole matter. At best, you have to say that what the Prime Minister has done in relation to One Nation and the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) has been a monumental incompetence. If you look at his handling of it, it has obviously been a double strategy, a situation in which the Prime Minister—before he was elected; when he became Leader of the Opposition—went around the country saying that he now believed in multiculturalism, that he now believed in giving everybody a fair go, and that he regretted his earlier views in 1988 about race and immigration. The member for Mitchell would know quite a lot about that because he was the shadow minister at the time.

What we heard from the Prime Minister before the last election was that he regretted all those views and he changed his position. Then, after the election, what did we have? When the member for Oxley made her first speech, he did not call her deranged, he did not say that her views were wrong, he did not say that there were any problems with her views. No, he said the only thing he could say at that time was that she had an absolute right to say what she wanted and it was about time somebody started talking in this way. That is all he had to say. As a result of that, a whole pandora's box has been opened up.

If you think that it is just a question of the Prime Minister's own standards, it is much more than that because it has done very serious damage to this country. It has done damage to this country in a number of ways not only internationally but also within our society. I have a lot of dealings with a lot of the ethnic communities in this country, and at many of the ethnic functions that I have been going to recently people from a number of ethnic backgrounds have not been coming up and saying, `We just disagree with the Prime Minister.' They have been saying, `For the first time in many years, we feel worried, afraid and concerned about our position in this country.' They say, `For the first time in many years, we are concerned that we are no longer going to be treated as equal citizens in this country, that there is a movement which is increasingly directed against us, directed against the values and ideas of equality and fairness in relation to this country.'

That was what the multicultural policy was all about. It was about fair and equal treatment. It was about treating people in an equal way, irrespective of their cultural, ethnic and racial background. That is what it was all about. There was a failure of leadership by the Prime Minister in relation to this matter and, as a result, we now have this ultra-conservative movement which has in fact been propounding ideas and views which have frightened people from ethnic backgrounds. That is what has happened.

Instead of the Prime Minister nipping this in the bud—he did not do that—he allowed it to flower. Suddenly it has come around and it has hurt the conservative parties, especially the Liberal Party, and what does he say? `Maybe we were wrong then. Maybe we should have done something more.' It is a bit too late after the horse has bolted, is it not? The situation now is that the Prime Minister regrets his earlier non-action in this matter.

The reality is that now we have a very serious problem in this country which we did not have to have. It is because of what has happened as a result of the Prime Minister's inactivity, as a result of the Prime Minister trying to have it both ways. On the one hand, he was trying to say to the ethnic communities that he supports multiculturalism but he was trying to say to the rest of Australia that, in fact, he is against multiculturalism and that he is against the ethnic community. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Don't you just love Labor? They really get off on saying one thing and doing another. Check out their form on the airport. Remember that—Sydney West airport? `Let's pick a site in the heart of Lindsay and then, on 2 March 1996 when we lose Lindsay, let's backflip, double flip and go round and find the most politically opportunist way that we could possibly act on this issue.' Give me a break!

speech.para: Eileen Cammack, our leading Liberal light in the area opposed that airport from when it was even remotely suggested all through her time in council many years ago. Anne Cohen fought that airport. As the Liberal member in Minchinbury she was a lone voice in the wilderness against people who were abusing her for protecting her own property interests in that area. Our own councillors—Leonie Jackson, Robin Wiles and Jim Aitken—have turned round Penrith City Council's views on the airport since we were elected in 1996. After all that we suddenly have a movement in western Sydney against the airport. But, guess what, it is so far after the original decision was made that we are sitting here playing catch-up. I have had to encourage the government to get the second EIS on the rails and to have another look at Labor's disastrous decision.

You can see something similar with the Lakes scheme. The decision on the Lakes scheme that is going on in Penrith was made years ago under a state Labor government. Suddenly, when it is impacting on people, Labor on council is out there trying to curry favour and grab votes by saying, `Oh, oh, we are terribly sorry. Isn't it dreadful?' Well, you made the decision. What about the `toaster' down there in Sydney? You suddenly want $200 million of taxpayers' funds to fix up your stuff-up after you made the decision. Now we have to come along and fix it up.

Look at the ADI site. There is state Labor planning minister Craig Knowles going hammer and tongs in favour of development. On council they want to get the politically opportunist spin on this and say, `Oh, it's not our decision. We'll lead the charge with the ADI residents action group.' The people of western Sydney are not that stupid. They have woken up to Labor. They have woken up to Labor's double standards of saying one thing and doing another: saying they are going in one direction and walking in another. They can talk the talk, but they never ever walk the walk. They have not gone the distance in western Sydney. After 13 years of Labor it is the most neglected area of Sydney. Yet they sit there and expect their solid grassroots dyed-in-the-wool Labor voters to still support them. They had very good reason to defect—to the Liberal Party.

But we intend to keep them in Lindsay because we are doing things for the area.
