We are acting, we are supporting their interests and we are listening to their concerns—listening to their aggravation that they can no longer get ahead. They are sitting there working 66-hour weeks for 10 cents in the dollar. That is their concern. Meanwhile, while they are working so hard, they see money being chucked off to this action group and over to this special interest group and over to this union group. They are fed up with that. They want someone who is going to deal with their mainstream issues, and that happens to be me. That is why I am in this parliament representing the people of Lindsay.

We will make sure for the people of Lindsay that we do not end up with an airport in our backyard. There will be a much more honest decision than any people had from the Labor Party. It will be consistent, it will be considered and it will be rational. We will be making the right decision by the people of Lindsay. I caution anyone who even remotely thinks of changing their vote on the airport issue to think about what Labor has offered. What did Labor really do over the protestations of the member for Chifley (Mr Price), the member for Fowler (Mr Grace) and the member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield)? Nothing, because they made a decision in the arrogance and isolation of leadership and went ahead with it. We have consulted with the community and we have listened to the people.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Before the House adjourns, I extend, on behalf of all the people of New England, my sympathy to the widow and family of the late Don Barwick. Don Barwick was a former Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, a very distinguished member of the United Farmers and woolgrowers association and a very successful farmer. His loss will be felt by all in New England and all who knew him. On behalf of everybody in rural Australia, I would like to extend to his family my own deep personal sympathy.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Customs Service: Counterfeit Cigarettes and Imported Vehicles
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1725)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 15 May 1997:

question.para: (1) Further to the former Minister's answer to part (2) of question No. 1049 (Hansard , 12 February 1997, page 863), is the Minister now able to provide additional information on the alleged customs scam; if so, what.

(2) Further to his answer to part (3) of question No. 1049 (a), what have been the results of the investigation carried out in relation to the alleged importation of 60 vehicles by a multi-millionaire and (b) has or will anyone be charged in relation to this matter; is so, who; if not why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The case concluded on 14 May 1998 when the NSW Magistrates Court accepted a Deed of Settlement between Customs and two of the defendants. $27,000 was the total of fines and costs and the 696,000 cigarettes were condemned and will be destroyed.

(2) (a) The investigation examined the circumstances of 18 imported vehicles, not 60, but finally centred on certain aspects concerning 2 particular vehicles. Testing of the evidence obtained from the investigation of those 2 vehicles concluded that it was insufficient to sustain action against any person. Additionally, a dispute remains unresolved between the importer and the Australian Customs Service about the applicability of a Customs by-law whereby duty on 4 cars was claimed as "free" by the importer. This matter is the subject of an on-going exchange of commentaries between the parties to the dispute and is not defined by Customs as an investigation. The balance of the vehicles is of no interest to Customs.
(2) (b) See the answer to (a).

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: Will the Australian Taxation Office pay refunds in cash: if not, (a) why not and (b) will it consider paying cash refunds to persons who do not have bank accounts into which they can deposit cheques.

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: No, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) will not pay refunds in cash.
(a) Taxation refunds are issued in accordance with Finance Regulation 68(1) which provides for payment by cheque, direct credit or Australian Government Credit Card.

(b) No, consistent with Finance Regulation 68(1), the ATO will not pay cash refunds to persons who do not have bank accounts. However, the ATO is willing to assist a person in such circumstances to have their refund cheque exchanged for cash by a financial institution.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) How many persons have been prosecuted for making false statements under provisions of the Migration Act with respect to misuse of the so-called $30 work visa.
(2) How many migration agents or other promoters colluding in the misuse of $30 work visas have been prosecuted.
(3) How many migration agents (a) have been, or (b) are to be, charged or (c) disciplined by the Migration Agents Registration Board in relation to the misuse of $30 work visas.
(4) How many cases of misuse of $30 work visas has his Department referred to the Australian Federal Police.
(5) Has he been advised on how to prevent the misuse of $30 work visas.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I believe the `so-called $30 work visa' colloquially refers to the application fee payable by persons not in immigration detention who lodge Protection Visa applications.

There are several nationalities which demonstrate high levels of protection visa application with low levels of grant of protection, indicating a pattern of abuse. For example, out of 2,231 protection visa applications from nationals of the Philippines concluded at primary level in 1996-97, 3 visas were granted. Similarly, 9 protection visas were granted to Indonesian nationals out of 1,976 applications concluded, while 52 protection visas were granted to nationals of the People's Republic of China out of 2,285 applications concluded. Out of 440 applications concluded from Fijians, and 414 from Tongans, none were granted protection visas.

Under the arrangements put in place by the previous Government, there were substantial processing delays for applicants at both primary and review levels. These delays create an incentive for non-citizens to lodge unfounded applications in order to extend their stay in Australia. The current Government has tightened considerably the access of protection visa applicants to work and welfare benefits while awaiting the outcome of their applications, and has accelerated processing of applications considerably. There are still options for further reducing incentives to lodge unfounded protection visa applications, and the Government will review them.

The appropriate sanction applied to asylum seekers whose claims for protection are unsubstantiated is removal from Australia as their existing visas expire. Prosecution is not normally considered effective, as the cost to the taxpayer is very high, the sentences obtained are often minimal and the whole exercise only serves to delay the claimant's departure from Australia.

(2) From the inception of the Migration Agents Registration Scheme until its closure on 21 March 1998, twenty-four migration agents or unregistered migration agents have been convicted or found guilty without recording a conviction. Three of the convictions included offences such as making a false instrument, or forging Commonwealth documents. The Department does not have specific records of whether each breach related to collusion in misuse of protection visa arrangements.

(3) During the period of operation of the Migration Agents Registration Scheme, 11 migration agents had their registration cancelled, 18 were suspended and a further 18 were cautioned for breaches of the code of conduct or other matters. The Department has not kept records of Migration Agents Registration Board prosecutions specifically associated with protection visa applications.

(4) The Department conducts its own investigations of breaches of the Migration Act 1958 and prepares briefs for the Director of Public Prosecutions. While it therefore does not refer cases to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for investigation, it cooperates with the AFP in investigations requiring search and arrest.

(5) Yes, and action has been taken. For example, the Migration Act 1958 has been amended to restrict access to work rights associated with protection visa applications. These changes, which commenced on 1 July 1997, restrict access to work rights and as a result Medicare, to those protection visa applicants who have been in Australia for less than 45 days in the past 12 months at time of application. By limiting access to work and Medicare the incentive to put in a frivolous protection visa application, simply in order to access these benefits, is significantly reduced.

The Department is also acting against agents who abuse the Protection Visa process by lodging frivolous or bogus applications on behalf of their clients. As an example of this ongoing action, an unregistered migration agent was recently arrested and charged with offences under the Migration Act 1958. The matter will come to Court shortly.

My Department's ability to deal quickly and effectively with immigration fraud will be considerably enhanced by the measures contained in Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997 currently before the Parliament. These proposed amendments to the Migration Act 1958, further streamline the cancellation of visas granted on the basis of false or fraudulent information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 23 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Will the transfer from Australian National (Track Access) to the Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) be a straight transformation of business under industrial law.
(2) Will existing employees be able to continue their employment with the ARTC.

(3) Will the Government use the transfer from one Commonwealth organisation to another to reduce conditions of employment; if not, will the Government undertake to maintain existing conditions of service.
(4) Will the Government sell the ARTC.
(5) Has the Government informed the South Australian Government that it will maintain operations at Port Augusta; if so, will it maintain the operations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the Workplace Relations Act 1996, the ARTC will be a successor to part of the business of the former AN.
(2) Staffing needs of the ARTC are currently being determined.

(3) AN awards will transmit and provide the basis of the no disadvantage test in setting terms and conditions of employees of the ARTC. For those employees transferred to the ARTC, accrued entitlements will be preserved and service will be considered continuous. Future conditions of service are a matter for the ARTC Board to determine with employees in negotiation of Australian Workplace Agreements or a new Certified Enterprise Agreement.
(4) The Government has no plans to sell the ARTC.

(5) The Government made a commitment that the national track company, the ARTC, will be based in South Australia. The ARTC is headquartered in Adelaide and has train control staff in Port Augusta. The ARTC made a commitment to the South Australian Government that the Port Augusta train control would not be moved while viable. It has no plans to close these operations at Port Augusta.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 26 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What sums did the (a) Defence Housing Authority (DHA) and (b) Department of Defence spend on legal costs and disbursements for an action in the High Court involving the DHA and the Residential Tenancies Tribunal of New South Wales in relation to four houses leased to the DHA.
(2) What sum in rental per week is the (a) DHA paying the owners and (b) Department of Defence paying the DHA for each house.
(3) Is there a shortage of houses for ADF personnel in the Sydney area; if so, (a) how many units of accommodation are required and (b) where are they required.

(4) Are any of the houses referred to in part (1) vacant; if so, (a) how many, (b) when does the DHA anticipate each will be occupied again by ADF personnel and (c) what is the remaining duration of the lease in each case.

(5) Did the High Court find that houses leased by the DHA from private sector owners were subject to the provisions of the Residential Tenancies Act (NSW) and the jurisdiction of the NSW Residential Tenancies Tribunal.
(6) Did the Residential Tenancies Tribunal order that the owners be allowed to inspect, and be provided with keys for, the properties; if so, on what date.
(7) Has the ADF advised the DHA that houses will be returned to it; if so, on what date in each case.
(8) Does the ADF recognise the need to comply with relevant State legislation in relation to houses occupied by ADF personnel in New South Wales.
(9) Have owners and occupants of DHA-leased houses been advised that relevant State legislation applies; if not, why not; if so, (a) when and (b) how was the information supplied.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The action in the High Court was in relation to the constitutional issue of whether the Residential Tenancies Tribunal of New South Wales, established under State laws, had jurisdiction over the Defence Housing Authority (DHA), a body established under Commonwealth law. The action commenced in April 1996. It was important for the DHA to clarify whether its leasings of properties from investors were subject to State tenancy laws, which regulate landlord-tenant relationships.
(a) The DHA spent $91,854 on legal costs and disbursements on the action, which was instituted on the basis of legal advice that it had constitutional immunity from State laws.
(b) The Department of Defence incurred no costs in relation to the action.

(2) (a) In the case of two of the four properties referred to, the DHA is paying the owner a gross rental of $450.21 per week for each property; in the other two cases the gross rent being paid is $471.89 per week for each property before deductions for any repair or management costs.
(b) The Department of Defence is paying the DHA rentals of $450.21 for each of the first mentioned properties, and $471.89 per week for each of the second mentioned properties.

(3) (a) (b) The numbers of houses provided are well matched to the requirements of ADF personnel in Sydney, although there is some turnover due to expiring leases or the need to upgrade homes from time to time.
(4) Yes.

(b) In accordance with the Residential Tenancies Act (NSW) 1987, the DHA has made application to the NSW Residential Tenancies Tribunal concerning maintenance and tenant's rights to quiet enjoyment of their homes. Pending the outcome of this application, the DHA is unable to make judgements about its possible future use of the properties.
(c) The unexpired period of each lease is about 4 1/2 years in two cases and about 5 years in the other two cases.
(5) Yes.
(6) Yes. Orders by consent were made on 18 September 1997 by the NSW Residential Tenancies Tribunal.

(7) Yes. On 15 October 1997, one Service advised DHA that a house would be handed back on vacancy. On 31 October 1997, another Service advised that there was no intention to reallocate the other three properties which would be returned to DHA upon vacancy.
(8) Yes.

(9) (a) (b) All ADF occupants were advised in the DHA's Spring 1997 newsletter. The Authority does not provide legal or commercial advice to owners of properties leased to the DHA, as the parties are in a commercial transaction.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 1 April 1998:

question.para: (1) By what administrative or legislative measures and to what extent has the number of local government bodies been increased or decreased in a State or Territory since the answer to question No 42 (Hansard , 28 June 1996, page 3199).
(2) What changes have there been to the configuration of voluntary regional organisations of councils and the size of their populations since the answer.

talker.name: Somlyay, Alex, MP
Mr Somlyay
talker.role: Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The number of local governing bodies in each State and the Northern Territory as at April 1998 is shown in the table below.
* number of local governing bodies as at answer to question No.221 (Hansard , 10 May 1995, page 281)
** number of local governing bodies as at answer to question No.42 (Hansard , 28 June 1996, page 3199)
In the period between May 1996 and April 1998, changes in the number of local governing bodies occurred in South Australia and the Northern Territory only.

In South Australia, structural reform during 1996-97 reduced the number of councils from 124 to 75. Mergers were voluntary against a background of State Government policy to reduce the number of councils under the auspices of South Australian Local Government Reform Board which recommended amalgamation proposals for Ministerial approval.

The Local Government (Boundary Reform) Act 1995 (S.A.) (amending the Local Government Act 1934 (S.A.)) was assented to by the Governor of South Australia in Executive Council on 21 December 1995. Under the provisions of the amended Local Government Act 1934 (S.A.), the South Australian Minister for Local Government can accept, reject or refer back the Board's report. If the Board's report is accepted by the Minister, the proposal recommended by the Board is forwarded to the Governor for the making of a Proclamation.
In the Northern Territory, one new local governing body was declared and one council deregistered with no net change to the total number of local governing bodies.
The Aboriginal community of Arltarlpilta (formerly the Atitjere Homelands Aboriginal

Corporation, Harts Range) was declared as a local governing body in October 1997, pursuant to section 3 of the Commonwealth Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1995. This followed a request to the Federal Minister from the Northern Territory Minister for Local Government for the declaration.

The Yulara Town Council (incorporating the Ayers Rock (Uluru) Resort community) was deregistered by the Northern Territory Minister in late 1997 under the Ayers Rock Resort (Sales) Act 1997 (N.T.). This followed a decision in November 1997 by the Northern Territory Government to sell the Resort to General Property Trust.
(2) In May 1996, there were 52 Voluntary Regional Organisations of Councils (VROCs) across all States covering about 54 per cent of all councils and 57 per cent of the population of Australia.

Since May 1996, one VROC has been established in Victoria while in South Australia it is too early to identify the resultant VROC structure following the structural reform processes. In New South Wales, ten local government bodies have withdrawn from the VROC structure.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 April 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the current schedule for vacation and relocation of the relevant facilities under the planned joint education organisation for officer education.
(2) What new buildings or premises are planned to accommodate the new organisation in (a) 1999, (b) 2000 and (c) 2001 and beyond.
(3) What is the estimated cost of each building or premises referred to in part (2).
(4) Which buildings or premises will be vacated.
(5) What will happen to the vacated facilities.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (2) and (3) The Australian College of Defence Studies (ACDSS) and the Joint Services Staff College (JSSC) are currently located at the Defence precinct at Weston Creek in the ACT. As part of the implementation of the Defence Reform Program, a new higher Defence course for senior officers to replace the JSSC and ACDSS courses is being developed. The new higher Defence course will be delivered at facilities at Weston Creek. Studies to support this are under way. The Navy, Army and Air Force Staff Colleges are also to be collocated, however, planning is at an early stage and no decision has been taken on a future site.

(4) At present, the Navy Staff College is based at HMAS Penguin at Balmoral in Sydney, the Army Staff College is at Fort Queenscliff south of Geelong, and the Air Force Staff College is at RAAF Base Fairbairn in Canberra.

(5) Discussions have been held with representatives of the Queenscliff community on the future of Fort Queenscliff. RAAF Base Fairbairn has been sold in conjunction with the sale of Canberra Airport. HMAS Penguin will continue as a functioning establishment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1998:

question.para: (1) How many war widows who remarried since May 1984 have retained their pension as a result of the legislative changes in 1986.
(2) What is the estimated number of war widows who remarried before May 1984 and (a) are still alive, (b) have been widowed a second time and (c) are separated or divorced from their second husband.
(3) Has the Government reviewed the treatment of war widows who remarried before May 1984; if so, (a) what were the recommendations of the review and (b) what changes has the Government made.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question are is follows:

answer.para: (1) Statistics of war widows who remarried since May 1984 and have retained their pension as a result of the legislative changes of 1986 are not readily available. The reason is that there is no requirement for a war widow who remarried after May 1984 to advise my Department of her change of personal circumstances unless she was in receipt of or applies for Income Support Supplement or income support from Centrelink.
(2) My Department does not have reliable figures, however estimated figures are: (a) 4,100; (b) 2,020; (c) 200.
(3) In 1994 an Inquiry into Compensation for Veterans and War Widows (the Baume Committee) considered the treatment of war widows who remarried prior to May 1984.
(a) The Committee recommended that the current pension rules relating to remarriage should remain in place.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: What is the (a) peacetime establishment and (b) current staffing strength of each unit in the Australian Army.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) and (b) The peacetime establishment of the Regular Army is 26,882 with the current staffing strength being 25,016. The peacetime establishment of the Army Reserve is 33,659 with the current effective strength being 24,656. I will provide the establishment and current staffing levels for each of the 288 headquarters and units in which Australian Army members are employed, directly to the honourable member as this detailed information is classified RESTRICTED.

The Army's establishment is currently under detailed review. The Restructuring the Army initiative which flowed from the Army in the 21st Century review, together with the implementation of the Defence Reform Program, will define the future establishment of the Army.

The honourable member will recall that in the context of the Defence Reform Program, and recently promulgated Government strategic policy, I have directed that the strength of the Regular Army is to be 23,000 within the overall ADF strength of 50,000.
The current plan within the Army is to have an effective Reserve strength of 27,000 by 30 June 2002.
The current gap between the Army's establishment and staffing levels will be reduced as the establishment is progressively adjusted to meet capability requirements and the target staffing levels.

As a result of the Defence Reform Program, combat and combat related positions across the ADF will increase to about 65 per cent of the Defence Force. New combat positions will be used, among other things, for Army units in Western Australia, Sydney and Melbourne, and ASLAV and Bushranger vehicles for Army.

(17) Did a GMAC meeting referred to in part (16) relate to an application for the use of genetically modified plants carrying a viral gene; if so, from what organisation did the application originate.

(18) Is there a conflict of interest if a member of GMAC (a) who takes part in GMAC discussions on plants that have been genetically modified to carry a viral gene is also involved in a project to develop plants of that kind, (b) who takes part in GMAC discussions of pest-resistant plants is employed by an organisation, agency or company that is working to develop pest-resistant transgenic plants or (c) is employed by an organisation, agency or company that has planned to benefit in any way from the use or development of genetically modified organisms.
(19) Has GMAC approved the release of virus-resistant transgenic plants for field testing or wider release since 13 March 1997; if so, which organisations were involved in developing the plants.
(20) Is a GMAC member a practising plant virologist or an expert on plant virus recombination; if so, (a) who and (b) what are the person's affiliations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Possible risks posed by virus-resistant transgenic plants were discussed at a session of the meeting on transgenic plants in March 1997. There was no general agreement among the scientists attending the session that the development of virus-resistant transgenic plants had advanced ahead of research on possible risks.
(2) Yes.
(a) The session on virus-resistant plants.
(b) Not applicable.

(3) In relation to proposals involving virus-resistant transgenic plants that GMAC had already considered, the Scientific Subcommittee concluded that the risks associated with such plants were not necessarily greater than the risks present during natural viral infection of plants; however, the Scientific Subcommittee also noted that new information on this issue would be taken into account as it became available.
(4) (a) Yes.
(b) Yes.

There is no conflict between the advice given to the Plant Industries Committee (that further research on the risks posed by virus-resistant transgenic plants may be needed) and the conclusion of GMAC (that it did not currently consider that the risks were necessarily greater than during natural infections of plants but that new information would be taken into account as it became available).
(5) Yes.

(a) Professor Jim Pittard (Scientific Subcommittee Chair), Professor Nancy Millis (GMAC Chair), Professor Ashley Dunn, Professor Peter Hudson, Associate Professor Peter Langridge, and Dr Ian Parsonson.

(b) University of Melbourne (Pittard, Millis), Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (Dunn), CSIRO Biomolecular Engineering (Hudson), Waite Agricultural Research Institute (Langridge) and retired from the CSIRO Australian Animal Health Laboratory (Parsonson).

(c) All the members listed in (a) and the two members of the Scientific Subcommittee who were not present at the meeting (Dr John Oakeshott (CSIRO Entomology) and Dr Jan Tennent (CSIRO Animal Health)).

(a) Members who did not attend the March 1997 meeting on transgenic plants (that is, all members apart from Professor Pittard, Professor Millis and Associate Professor Langridge) did not receive the papers.
(b) See answer to (a).

(c) Members were not given the papers because the issue of virus-resistant plants was not an agenda item at the Scientific Subcommittee meeting on 1 August 1997. The issue was only discussed in the context of correspondence that had been received on this matter, and the members of the Scientific Subcommittee who had been present at the March 1997 meeting reported orally to the Scientific Subcommittee on the papers presented at that meeting.
(a) See answer to (7).
(b) See answer to (7).
(9) Professor Jim Pittard, Chair of the Scientific Subcommittee.
(10) No, because there was no such agreement.
(11) No. GMAC members have expertise in different specialist areas.
(13) Dr John Oakeshott.
(15) Dr Robyn van Heeswijck.
Dr Oakeshott: Scientific Subcommittee meeting on 2 July 1992; Planned Release Subcommittee meeting on 24 November 1995.
Dr van Heeswijck: Planned Release Subcommittee meetings on 14 July 1994; 2 June 1995; 10 September 1996; 30 May 1997.

(17) Yes. At the meetings referred to in part (16), applications for plants carrying viral genes from the following organisations were assessed: CSIRO Plant Industry, Agriculture Victoria, La Trobe University, Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, University of Western Australia.

(18) (a) GMAC members undertake to inform the Chair immediately if they become aware of any possible conflict of interest between their responsibilities as a member and their personal, business or financial interests. GMAC members sign a declaration to this effect on their appointment to GMAC and stand aside from Committee discussions where there is a potential conflict of interest.
(b) See answer to (a).
(c) See answer to (a).

(19) Yes. Since March 1997, GMAC has advised that proposals for field testing of virus-resistant transgenic plants from the following organisations may proceed: Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations, University of Western Australia, CSIRO Plant Industry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: Did the Minister's Department advise health care card holders that travel concessions were available (a) only to Newstart, sickness allowance and special benefit recipients in mid 1997 and (b) also available to widow's allowance and youth training allowance recipients in late 1997; if so, did the changed advice result from intervening changes in legislation or regulations; if not, what steps are being taken to compensate health care card holders who were wrongly charged full fares.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) The information provided with Health Care Cards in Victoria previously advised that travel concessions were only available to Newstart, Sickness Allowance and Special Benefit recipients. This information was provided by the Victorian Department Human Services (VDHS).

(b) A request was made by VDHS on 23 July 1997 to update the information provided with Health Care Cards regarding the availability of transport concessions to Widow Allowance and Youth Training Allowance recipients. These changes were implemented in August 1997.
Any changes to information provided with Health Care Cards relating to travel concessions are made in response to requests from the relevant state or territory agencies.

The provision of travel concessions, and information relating to those concessions, is a state / territory responsibility. Compensation is an issue for the relevant state or territory government to address.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Who is permitted to use the Australian coat of arms.
(2) When may it be used.
(3) Is its use governed by Acts of Parliament; if so, which Acts.
(4) What authority does the Olympic Games Committee have to use the Australian coat of arms.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth Coat of Arms is a symbol of Commonwealth government authority, power and ownership. It is for the principal use by Commonwealth government departments and non-trading Commonwealth authorities. On a case by case basis, the Awards and National Symbols Branch of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet will consider exceptions to this general restriction. The exceptions made to date include permission to place the Commonwealth Coat of Arms on the sporting apparel of competitively selected Australian sporting teams competing internationally, and other similar teams, such as those competing in skill olympics; and permission to reproduce the Commonwealth Coat of Arms in educational books and publications.

(2) The Commonwealth Coat of Arms may be used to identify Commonwealth owned or occupied buildings and on formal letterhead and publications used by or produced by Commonwealth departments and non-trading authorities. It may also be used on the uniforms and credentials of Commonwealth officials.

(4) In common with the procedures required of any sporting body seeking to have the Commonwealth Coat of Arms placed on the sporting apparel of their competitively selected athletes, the Australian Olympic Games Committee periodically seeks, and obtains, approval from the Awards and National Symbols Branch of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 1 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Government recently announced a pilot program to increase the number of women on public sector boards.

(2) Has the executive search firm, Profile Ray and Berndtson, been selected by the Office of the Status of Women to draw up lists of women for appointment to public sector positions; if so, (a) what total fee will be paid to the firm for the work, (b) did the selection of the firm follow a formal tender process; if not, why not, (c) did the firm manage the selection of Ms Pru Goward as Head of the Office of the Status of Women and (d) is it a fact that apart from some contracts with the ACT Government, including significant fees for oral advice, that the firm had limited involvement in the Canberra and Commonwealth Government market before March 1996.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, on 27 March 1998, the Prime Minister announced an Executive Search Pilot Program and an Early Warning System, to help increase the number of women appointed to Commonwealth boards and bodies.
(2) The firm, Profile Ray and Berndtson, has been selected to provide assistance as part of the Executive Search Pilot Program.
(a) The firm is paid $400.00 per nominee. Travel and accommodation disbursements are in addition to this cost.
(b) The selection of the firm followed an open tender process.
(c) The firm provided executive search services as part of the selection process for the position of Head of the Office of the Status of Women.
(d) I am unable to comment on Profile Ray and Berndtson's involvement in the Canberra and Commonwealth Government market before March 1996.
